revision.text:
{{Infobox company | slogan = | name = The Legendary House of Aviance | logo = | caption = | type = [[Ball culture#Houses|Ballroom House]] | founder= [[Mother Juan Aviance]] | foundation = August 1989 — Present
(Founded in [[Washington, D.C.|D.C]]) | location_city = [[New York City]] | location_country = [[United States|U.S.]] | key_people = [[Mother Juan Aviance]], Daddy Tony Aviance, [[Kevin Aviance]], John Aviance, [[Papa Joe Aviance]], [[Jean-Philippe Aviance]], [[Erickatoure Aviance]], David Ohana Aviance, [[Tamsier Joof Aviance]], William Aviance | industry = | products = | revenue = | num_employees= | parent = | subsid = |homepage=[http://houseofaviance.com/ House of Aviance]
[http://aviancerecords.com/ Aviance Records, LLC] | footnotes = The Legendary House of Aviance is known for its [[vogue (dance)|vogue dancers]], [[Disc jockey|DJs]], [[music]], [[Record producer|music producers]], [[performing art|performances]], [[runway (fashion)|runways]] and [[fashion]], and is one of the longest continuously active [[ball culture#Houses|houses]] in [[ball culture]]. }} '''The House of Aviance''' ([[acronym]]: '''HOA''') is one of the ''"[[Ball culture#Houses|legendary]]"'' and major [[vogue (dance)|vogue]]-[[Ball culture#Houses|ball houses]] in the [[United States]], with its base in [[New York City]].Desmond, Jane , ''"Dancing desires: choreographing sexualities on and off the stage"'', [[University of Wisconsin Press]] (2001), p. 435, {{ISBN|9780299170509}}Lewis, Darvin , ''"How Big Is Your Faith: The Gospel of Down Low Fiction"''. p. 120,{{ISBN|9781434833471}} (2008) [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=YEjREFmJP7cC&pg=PA129#v=onepage&q&f=false]{{cite web|url=http://aviancerecords.com/|publisher=aviancerecords.com|title=The Legendary House of Aviance in Aviance Records official website |accessdate=2017-07-11}} It was founded in [[Washington, D.C.]] in 1989 by [[vogue (dance)|voguer]]/dancer, [[record label]] owner ([[Chief executive officer|CEO]]/[[artists and repertoire|A&R]]), [[Promoter (entertainment)|nightclub host]], [[Musician|music artist]] and secretary [[Mother Juan Aviance]]—one of the [[nightlife]] personalities of New York City.{{cite web|url=http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2546627|publisher=brownpapertickets.com|title=Kevin Aviance at Pangea |accessdate=2017-07-11}}''"Mother Juan Aviance Bio and House of Aviance History"'' [in] the official website of The House of Aviance [http://houseofaviance.com/]Thotyssey : ''"On Point With: Mother Juan Aviance"'' (June 21st, 2017) Since its founding, the House has played an integral part in U.S and world [[ball culture]], especially U.S. nightlife. The House of Aviance is one of the longest continuously active Houses to have emerged from the ball scene and is sometimes referred to as "a working house" with membership from all works of life, sexualities and genders. Its membership include [[dance]]rs, musicians, [[Disc jockey|DJs]], [[drag queen]]s, [[Performance art|performing artists]], [[Visual arts|visual artists]], [[Singing|singers]], [[songwriter]]s, [[Record producer|music producers]] and engineers.[[Huffington Post]]: ''"After Dark: Erickatoure Aviance, Artist And Nightlife Personality"'' by James Michael Nichols (August /24, 2014, updated February 02, 2016) [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/08/24/erickatoure-aviance-after_n_5703627.html] The Legendary House of Aviance is especially known for its voguers, performances, [[Runway (fashion)|runways]], [[fashion]], music, music producers and DJs. Its membership as of 2014 is just over 700 worldwide. Most of its members are or have been part of nightlife in one way or another. The House has for a long time stopped competing (''walking''Susman, Tara ([[Columbia University]]), ''"The Vogue of Life: Fashion Culture, Identity, and the Dance of Survival in the Gay BalIs"'', disClosure: A Journal of Social Theory, p. 118 (PDF p.3 ) [in] UKnowledge [http://uknowledge.uky.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1220&context=disclosure]) in the ball scene, and as such, "is not exactly like the voguing houses of [[Jennie Livingston]]'s film [[Paris Is Burning (film)|Paris Is Burning]], since it does not compete. The House of Aviance is something of a [[queer]] kinship network in which members serve as extended, pretended, and—some would argue—improved family that supports and enables its members."Muñoz, José Esteban, ''"Cruising Utopia: The Then and There of Queer Futurity"'', NYU Press (2009), p. 75, {{ISBN|9780814757284}} [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=f1MTCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA75#v=onepage&q&f=false] ==History== The House of Aviance was founded in August 1989 by [[Mother Juan Aviance]]. The House began in [[Washington, D.C.]] on 1420 Harvard Street before it was moved in 1993 to [[New York City]] by Mother Juan. Since its move, New York has become its base, but it still plays an active role in New York and Washington DC's nightlife as well as other cities in the U.S. Since its inception, it has become one of the major Houses in New York's [[ball culture|ballroom]] and [[vogue (dance)|voguing]] scene having won many trophies and cash prizes for their performances in ball competitions before the House ultimately stopped ''walking balls'' altogether.Thump : ''"We Asked Two Quintessential NYC Queer DJs About the Art of the All-Night Set"'' by Steve Weinstein (November 20, 2015) [https://thump.vice.com/en_ca/article/we-asked-two-quintessential-nyc-queer-djs-about-the-art-of-the-all-night-set] Previously, The House of Aviance was called ''The House of Power''. That remained the name for few weeks during its inception until Mother Juan decided to change it to ''The House of Aviance''. According to Mother Juan, he was glancing at a vendor's cart on the streets of DC. The vendor was selling [[perfume]]s. As Mother Juan glanced at the cart, he remembered a [[Television advertisement|commercial]] from his childhood days by [[Prince Matchabelli]]. That commercial contained a [[Melody|tune]] with the [[lyrics]]: ''"We're going to have an Aviance Night."'' In an [[Epiphany (feeling)|epiphany]], Mother Juan decided to rename the House to ''The House of Aviance''. Since then, the name of the House's has remained the same. To commemorate their second anniversary, The House of Aviance threw its first ball on Sunday, August 11, 1991 titled ''"The Inferno Ball at Tracks DC"''. Most of the notable New York and DC houses walked that night, including Aviance members. Some of the judges that night included the ''icons'' [[Dorian Corey]] and [[Pepper LaBeija]], both featured in the acclaimed [[Paris Is Burning (film)|Paris Is Burning]] film a year earlier.The flyer of The House of Aviance first ball can be seen in Mother Juan Aviance's Facebook page [https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10150284368849430&set=a.69627699429.68369.686409429&type=1&theater] Since its founding, Mother Juan Aviance has remained the ''"House Mother"'', and Daddy Tony Aviance the ''"House Father"''. As of 2017, they are two of the longest serving and continuously active ''house parents'' in [[ball culture#Houses|ballroom house]] history. The House of Aviance's first DJ was [[Jean-Philippe Aviance]] who went on to produce ''Go Bitch Go! – "Work This Pussy"'' (Original Bitch Mix) in 1991, ''Useless, Give Me Luv – Alcatraz'' and several other tracks. ==Influences== ===Voguing=== The Aviance style of voguing is referred to as "Aviance Storytelling". It is based on graceful, sharp and elegant lines with great fluidity and a high degree of experimentation and individuality.John Aviance bio [in] The House of Aviance official website [http://houseofaviance.com/2013/10/03/john-aviance/] Fluidity is key in Aviance Storytelling. The style is [[narrative]] in structure and form, punctuated by an "A" or heart-like [[Motif (narrative)|motif]] in certain phrases symbolizing the name of the House or the House's [[logo]] (''The Sacred Heart of Aviance''). ===Music=== The House of Aviance through its multi-genre record label ([[Aviance Records, LLC]]) has over the years produced [[House music|house tracks]] like ''Avi'ously Aviance'' produced by David Ohana Aviance and featuring [[EJ Aviance]], [[Kevin Aviance]], Perry Aviance and Mother Juan Aviance; ''OVAH'' by [[Erickatoure Aviance]]; ''I Am Art'' by EJ Aviance; and the [[soul music|soulful track]] ''They Don't See'' — a collaboration between producer/remixer Call Me Cleve (Cleveland Allen) and vocalist Zhana Roiya.''"Untucked- 'I Am Art' EJ Aviance"'' [in] David Atlanta (March 11, 2013)[http://davidatlanta.com/2013/03/untucked-i-art-ej-aviance/] One of the most highly acclaimed musicians to have emerged from The House of Aviance is Kevin Aviance with House anthems like ''Alive'', ''Cunty (The Feeling)'', ''Gimme More (Aviance)'', and ''Din Da Da''.''"Venus, Volume 6, Issue 5"'', Venus Magazine (2000), p. 19 The House of Aviance's first DJ [[Jean-Philippe Aviance]]'s 1991 track ''Go Bitch Go! – "Work This Pussy"'' (Original Bitch Mix) has been covered and released numerous times by some highly acclaimed DJs such as [[Armand Van Helden]] in his 2014 ''Masterpiece''.Music Times : ''"Armand Van Helden's 'Masterpeice' To Be Released Feb. 15 On Ministry of Sound"'' by Ryan Middleton (December 24, 2014) [http://www.musictimes.com/articles/21679/20141224/armand-van-helden-masterpeice-released-feb-15-ministry-of-sound-tracklist.htm] [[Britney Spears]]' 2013 track ''[[Work Bitch]]'' from her ''[[Britney Jean]]'' album is reported by [[music critics|critics]] like Barry Walters as a recreation of ''"the [[vogue (dance)|vogueing]] vibe of gay/trans bitch tracks like Go Bitch Go's "(Work This) Pussy"'' [Go Bitch Go! – "Work This Pussy"] originally produced by Jean-Philippe Aviance in 1991.''"Britney Spears Goes Blanker Than Usual on the Nightmarish 'Britney Jean'"'' by Barry Walters (December 3, 2013) [in] Spin [http://www.spin.com/2013/12/britney-spears-britney-jean-worst-new-music/] According to critic Christina Lee, Britney's ''Work Bitch'' track sounds more like [[RuPaul]]'s 1993 track ''[[Supermodel of the World|Supermodel (You Better Work)]]''.''"Britney Spears' "Work Bitch" Hits The Web Early: Listen To The Club Banger That Works (Bitch)'"'' by Christina Lee (September 15, 2013) [in] IDOLATOR [http://www.idolator.com/7484328/britney-spears-work-bitch] In 2009, DJs [[Chris Cox (DJ)|Chris Cox]] and Yiannis Mistress remixed [[Chris Cox (DJ)#2009|Jean-Phillippe Aviance's ''"Giv Me Luv"'' track starring Dihann Moore]].{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/DJ-Yiannis-Reloaded/release/2260359|publisher=discogs.com|title=DJ Yiannis* - Reloaded (CD) at Discogs |accessdate=2017-07-11}}Beat Box - Dance /Electronic : ''"Success Of DJ Collections Will Reflect State Of Industry"'' by Michael Paoletta [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=mA0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA39#v=onepage&q&f=false] DJ/Producer David Ohana is a member of the House as well as business partner in Aviance Records.Biography of David Ohana Aviance [in] Aviance Records official website [http://aviancerecords.com/bio/] ===Fashion=== "The Aviance look" is generally referred to as ''Avi'ously Aviance''. The style is flamboyant, big and glamorous. ===Coined phrases=== The House of Aviance is also known in the ballroom scene for their coined phrases which in essence describes their "look" (the Aviance look) in reference to their sense of fashion, their voguing style and performance. Some of these coined phrases include: *''"Avi'ously Aviance"'' : This is in reference to their sense of fashion - big, glamorous and flamboyant. The debut track released by Aviance Records is titled ''Avi'ously Aviance''.''Avi'ously Aviance'' by David Ohana Aviance, feat. EJ Aviance, Kevin Aviance, Perry Aviance & Mother Juan Aviance (2014) on Itunes [https://itunes.apple.com/bw/album/aviously-aviance-feat.-ej/id950691794] *''"Aviance Storytelling"'' : This is in reference to their voguing style - elegant, graceful, sharp, fluid, [[narrative]] in structure and form, and punctuated by an "A" or [[heart]]-like shaped [[Motif (narrative)|motif]] in certain phrases, symbolizing ''Aviance'' or their House logo (''"The Sacred Heart of Aviance"''). *''"Work. Fierce. Over. Aviance!"'' : This is the coined phrase and trademark of The House of Aviance's oldest daughter [[Kevin Aviance]].Kevin Aviance [in] ''"Famous Gay African-American Men"'' [in] We Are Members [http://www.wearemembersofthiscommunity.org/famous-gay-african-american-men.html] It is in reference to their [[Runway (fashion)|runway]]. *''"Avi'Who? Avi'What? It's Aviance darling!"'' (other variation: ''"Avi'What? Avi'Where? Isn't it Avi'ous darling!"'') : This is in reference to their music and the "fierceness" of the House in general. This chant can be heard on the first track released by Aviance Records titled ''Avi'ously Aviance''.Papa Joe Aviance bio [in] The House of Aviance official website [http://houseofaviance.com/2013/10/03/papa-joe-aviance/] ==Why the House doesn't walk balls anymore== {{quote box|width=25em|align=right|quote=My concern for the kids/members of the House far overshadows my desire for Ballroom fame ... Some of the kids are fragile and want and need to be accepted and/or belong, but if they make one wrong move on the runway they are verbally abused and humiliated in front of their peers. In my opinion, I think people should be treated with more dignity and respect than what I've witnessed in the Ballroom. But make no mistakes I love the concept and despite all the things I find objectionable about the Ballroom I do remember where I came from.|salign=right |source=—[[Mother Juan Aviance]]"}} Despite winning numerous trophies and cash prizes for their performances in ballroom competitions over the years, the House suddenly stopped walking. According to Mother Juan, he decided to stop his House kids from walking balls because of "Ballroom politics", unfair judging and the negative atmosphere of the ballroom, such as verbal abuse, intimidation and humiliation especially where kids "make one wrong move on the runway." ==Current role== The House is still an active "working house" with over 700 members [[world]]wide and regularly hold events/performances. Members still work or perform in their respective fields with support and guidance from house parents - Mother Juan and Daddy Tony as well as other family members. The House's oldest daughter — [[Kevin Aviance]] made special appearances in [[Wolfgang Busch]]'s 2006 documentary ''[[How Do I Look]]''.Porter. Darwin ; Prince, Danforth , ''"Blood Moon's guide to gay and lesbian film"'', Blood Moon Productions, Limited (2007), p. 247.{{ISBN|9780974811871}} The [[Documentary film|documentary]] was a chronicle of the [[ball culture]] in [[Harlem]]. With the [[HIV]] and [[AIDS]] epidemic affecting the ballroom scene for decades, The House of Aviance is no exception, and the House and its membership has for years taken active roles in HIV/AIDS awareness and prevention as well as throwing charity events to support organisations like the [[Gay Men's Health Crisis|GMHC]]."ON APRIL 10th - YOUTH HIV/AIDS AWARENESS DAY w/ DJ BOLO AVIANCE and MORE!" [in] Official House of Aviance Blog [http://houseofaviance.blogspot.co.uk/2014/04/on-april-10th-youth-hivaids-awareness.html]"Avi'ously Aviance Glamatron Runway" (Glamatron fundraiser for GMHC) in Aviance Record's official YouTube Channel (2015) [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zY04QKKBTmE] ==Some notable members== *[[Mother Juan Aviance]] - founder of HOA, ''House Mother'', entrepreneur and voguer (U.S.) *Daddy Tony Aviance - ''House Father'' *[[Kevin Aviance]] - nightlife personality, drag artist and musician (U.S.) *[[Erickatoure Aviance]] - artist and nightlife personality (U.S.)[[NBC New York]]: ''"Drag Queen Erickatoure Aviance: Nightlife Has "Changed Drastically"'' by Mawuse Ziegbe (April 15, 2010) [http://www.nbcnewyork.com/blogs/niteside/Drag-Performer-Erickatoure-Aviance-New-York-Superclubs-Are-Gone-Forever-90921864.html] *[[Jean-Philippe Aviance]] - DJ and music producer (U.S.) *[[Tamsier Joof Aviance]] - dancer/voguer, choreographer, radio personality and entrepreneur. *[[Nita Aviance]] - former dancer turned DJ and a member of Carry Nation.The [[New York Times]], ''The Carry Nation, a Downtown D.J. Duo, Drums Up a Hypnotic Beat', by Michael Musto, June 28, 2017 [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/28/fashion/the-carry-nation-downtown-dj-duo-gay-clubs.html]Thump - Vice, ''We Asked Two Quintessential NYC Queer DJs About the Art of the All-Night Set'', by Steve Weinstein, November 20, 2015 [https://thump.vice.com/en_us/article/xypy37/we-asked-two-quintessential-nyc-queer-djs-about-the-art-of-the-all-night-set] *Kim Aviance - performance and visual artistPaper Mag, ''Catching Up With Past Nightlife Awards Winners: Happy Valley'', by Abby Schreiber, 17 October 2013 [http://www.papermag.com/catching-up-with-past-nightlife-awards-winners-happy-valley-1427113785.html] ==References== {{reflist|35em}} {{portal|African American|LGBT|Dance|Music|Fashion}} ==External links== *The House of Aviance official website [http://houseofaviance.com/] *The House of Aviance and Aviance Record's official blog [http://houseofaviance.blogspot.co.uk/] *Mother Juan Aviance's official [[YouTube]] Channel capturing HOA's performances and events over the years [https://www.youtube.com/user/motherjuanaviance] *Aviance Records, LLC official website [http://aviancerecords.com/] *Aviance Records, LLC official YouTube Channel [https://www.youtube.com/user/aviancerecords] {{commons|:category:House of Aviance|The House of Aviance}} {{Ball culture|state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aviance, The House of}} [[Category:House of Aviance]] [[Category:New York City nightlife]] [[Category:LGBT African-American culture]] [[Category:LGBT culture in New York City]] [[Category:LGBT culture in Washington (state)]] [[Category:Ballroom houses]]

{{Infobox game | name = Icehouse pieces | subtitle = | image = Icehouse_pieces.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = Various Icehouse pieces | caption = Various Icehouse pieces | width = | label_width = | other_names = {{ubl|Icehouse pyramids|Treehouse Pyramids|Looney Pyramids (official)}} | AKA = | manufacturer = Grand Prix International | designer = John Cooper
[[Andrew Looney]] | illustrator = | actor = | voice_over = | publisher = [[Looney Labs]] | date = {{release date and age|mf=yes|1989}} | years = 1987-present | genre = Game system | language = | system = | players = | ages = | setup_time = | playing_time = | random_chance = | skills = | materials = | media_type = | blank_label = | blank_data = | website = {{url|icehousegames.com}} | footnotes = }} '''Icehouse pieces''', or '''Icehouse Pyramids''', '''Treehouse pieces''', '''Treehouse Pyramids''' and officially '''Looney Pyramids''', are nestable and stackable [[pyramid]]-shaped gaming pieces and a game system. The game system was invented by [[Andrew Looney]] and John Cooper in 1987, originally for use in the game of [[Icehouse (game)|Icehouse]].{{cite news|last1=Liu|first1=Jonathan H.|title=Looney Pyramids Are Back|url=http://archive.wired.com/geekdad/2013/01/looney-pyramids/|accessdate=June 8, 2015|work=Wired|agency=Geek Dad|publisher=Condé Nast|date=January 3, 2013|archiveurl=http://geekdad.com/2013/01/looney-pyramids/|archivedate=January 3, 2013}} ==History== Andrew Looney in 1987 penned a sci-fi short story,{{cite news|last1=Barnes|first1=Denise|title=The Looneys devise a game plan|url=http://www.wunderland.com/LooneyLabs/WashingtonTimes.8.27.98.html|accessdate=June 18, 2015|work=Washington Times|date=August 27, 1998}} "The Empty City", that included a game called Icehouse, an ancient Martian game.{{cite journal|last1=West|first1=Susan|title=The Looney Labs Experiment|journal=GAMES|volume=October 2005|url=http://www.wunderland.com/LooneyLabs/Press/200510_gamesmag.html|accessdate=June 16, 2015}} Readers of the short story requested to learn how to play the game. Thus actual rules were invented for Icehouse by Andrew Looney, Kristin Wunderlich (then future wife of Looney) and John Cooper, then plastic pyramid pieces were made to play the game. The first commercially available set were solid non-stackable pyramids released in 1989 with only 100 sets made. The pieces were made from resin in his apartment, which upset the landlord.{{cite news|last1=Ford|first1=C. Benjamin|title=Looneys working through the serious business of fun|url=http://ww2.gazette.net/gazette_archive/2002/200247/business/news/132311-1.html|accessdate=June 16, 2015|work=The Gazette|publisher=Post Community Media, LLC|date=November 22, 2002}} After several years, Looney shut down Icehouse Games, Inc. and soon started another gaming company, [[Looney Labs|Looney Laboratories]], in 1996.{{cite news|title=History of Icehouse Games, 1987-1998|url=http://wunderland.com/icehouse/IcehouseHistory1987-98.html|accessdate=June 22, 2015|work=wunderland.com|publisher=Looney Labs|date=1998}} Additional games beyond Icehouse were created including [[Martian chess|Martian Chess]], [[Zendo (game)|Zendo]], and Homeworlds. Looney then created the [[IceTowers]] game which used stacking pyramids leading to a change in the pyramid pieces' specification for stacking. The four games were released as a part of Icehouse: The Martian Chess Set, which was the first Icehouse pyramid system release by Looney Labs. In 2001, Icehouse: The Martian Chess Set won the [[Origins Award]] for ''Best Abstract Board Game of 2000''.{{cite news|last1=Jackson|first1=Micah|title=Origins Awards Announced: Pyramid Wins Best Magazine|url=http://www.sjgames.com/pyramid/origins2000.html|accessdate=June 8, 2015|work=Pyramid Magazine|publisher=Steve Jackson Games|date=July 7, 2001}} Icehouse was recognized as a game system in the game design textbook ''Rules of Play'' by Katue Salen and Eric Zimmerman. By June 21, 2002, Icehouse pieces were being sold in tubes containing a stash, or 15 pyramids of a single color, with nine colors available. Labs then released the book ''Playing With Pyramids'', which contained a dozen games by the Looneys, Cooper, Kory Heath and Jacob Davenport.{{cite magazine |date=June 21, 2002 |title=Playing with Pyramids: 12 Games for Icehouse Pieces |url=http://www.sjgames.com/pyramid/sample.html?id=2852 |magazine=Pyramid |department=Pyramid Pick |series= |language= |edition= |location= |publisher=Steve Jackson Games |publication-date= |volume=2 |issue= |access-date=May 25, 2017 }} In 2004, the Zendo boxed set won ''Best Abstract Board Game of 2003'',{{cite news|title=Origins Award Winners for 2003|url=http://icv2.com/articles/games/view/5173/origins-award-winners-for-2003|accessdate=June 8, 2015|work=ICv2|date=June 28, 2004}} In 2005 the set won the Mensa Select Game Award.{{cite web |last1=Arneson |first1=Erik |title=Mensa Select Award Winners |url=http://boardgames.about.com/od/awards/a/mensa_select.htm |website=About |accessdate=June 24, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626134309/http://boardgames.about.com/od/awards/a/mensa_select.htm |archivedate=June 26, 2015 |df= }} While in 2007, [[Treehouse (game)|Treehouse]] won the Origins Award for ''Best Board Game of 2006''.{{cite news|title=2007 Origins Award Winners|url=http://icv2.com/articles/games/view/10881/2007-origins-award-winners|accessdate=June 8, 2015|work=ICv2|date=July 9, 2007}} Looney Labs relaunched the Icehouse pieces as "Looney Pyramids" with new packaging with its IceDice set in June 2011{{cite news|last1=Niebling|first1=William|title=Review of 'IceDice'|url=http://icv2.com/articles/games/view/19745/review-icedice|accessdate=June 10, 2015|work=ICv2|date=March 30, 2011}} followed by Pink Hijinks in December 2012.{{cite news|last1=Niebling|first1=William|title=Review: 'Looney Pyramids'--'Treehouse' AND 'Pink Hijinks'|url=http://icv2.com/articles/games/view/24620/review-looney-pyramids-treehouse-pink-hijinks|accessdate=June 10, 2015|work=ICv2|date=December 17, 2012}} By 2013, the IcehouseGames.org website listed 400 games playable with icehouse pyramids. Original prototype under the name of ''Pyramid Throwdown'' in 2015, ''Pyramid Arcade'' was launched as a [[Kickstarter]] campaign on April 5, 2016.{{cite news|title=Kickstarter Tabletop Alert: 'Pyramid Arcade'|url=https://geekdad.com/2016/04/pyramid-arcade/|accessdate=May 25, 2017|work=GeekDad|date=April 5, 2016}} The new boxed pyramid set was funded in under 12 hours. Racking up $150 thousand total, the set shipped to supporters in fall 2016.{{cite news|last1=Liu|first1=Jonathan H.|title=Reaping the Rewards: Looney Labs' 'Pyramid Arcade'|url=https://geekdad.com/2016/10/pyramid-arcade-2/|accessdate=May 25, 2017|work=GeekDad|date=October 18, 2016}} == Description == [[File:Icehouse pieces paper and plastic.jpg|Icehouse pieces in paper and plastic|thumb]] The pieces are four-sided pyramids that can nest and stack with [[pip (counting)|pip]]ping from 1 to 3 at the base. A group of three pyramids, one of each size, is called a "trio." Each "stash" or set of Icehouse pieces consists of five trios, or fifteen pyramids (variously called pieces, pyramids, or minions) of the same color and five of each three sizes: five large 3-point pyramids (called "queens" in some games), five medium 2-point pyramids (sometimes called "drones"), and five small 1-point pyramids (or "pawns").{{citation needed|date=June 2015}} The stacked and nested feature is not used in the original Icehouse game, but is taken advantage of in some of the other Icehouse-based games listed below. Icehouse pieces were, for many years, sold as tubes containing one stash of durable crystal-look plastic pieces in one of ten available colors (though cyan was only available through their promotional program or as part of the Ice Towers set). There was also a less expensive starter set called Origami Icehouse (later called Paper Icehouse), made of cardstock in four colors, which one punched out and folded into the pyramid shapes. In 2006, [[Looney Labs]] began selling Icehouse pieces as ''Treehouse sets'', which are multicolored sets of 15 pyramids: five colors, each color having one each of the three sizes. Looney Labs has also sold boxed sets for [[Zendo (game)|Zendo]] and [[IceTowers]]; the latter contained cyan pieces.{{citation needed|date=June 2015}} The Icehouse website also has instructions for making your own pieces. Looney Labs has licensed [[Crystal Caste]] to make regulation-sized Icehouse pieces out of semiprecious [[gemstone|stone]]. Beginning with its Looney Pyramids relaunch set, IceDice, the sets are packaged in pyramid shaped nylon zipper bag. ==Releases== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Set !! pieces || games || released{{cite web|title=Out Of Print (OOP) Pyramid Products|url=http://wunderland.com/icehouse/BlackIce/Default.html|website=Wunderland|publisher=Looney Labs|accessdate=June 10, 2015}} |- !colspan=4| ===IceHouse Games=== |- | Icehouse (The Original Black Box) |rowspan=2| standard color stash |rowspan=4| [[Icehouse (game)|Icehouse]] || {{dts|1989}} |- |rowspan=2| Paper Icehouse ("Origami" Icehouse) |rowspan=2| {{dts|1991}} |- || Neon stash |- | Xyloid Icehouse || wood standard color stash || {{dts|1992}} |- !colspan=4| ===Looney Labs stack-able=== |- | The Martian Chess Set (MCS) || 2 standard color stash in plastic box || [[Martian Chess]], [[IceTowers]], IceTraders & Zarcana

for future rule book (3HOUSE) || {{dts|2000}} |- | Giant Cardboard Pyramids || || |rowspan=3| {{dts|2001}} |- | Icehouse Pieces monochrome stash tubes || one color stash || {{n/a|none}} |- | ''Playing with Pyramids'' booklet (PwP) || {{n/a|none}} || IceTowers, Thin Ice, Zendo, Martian Backgammon, Volcano, [[Martian Chess]], RAMbots, Pikemen, Zagami, Homeworlds, Gnostica, and the original Icehouse |- | Zendo boxed set || 2 standard color stashes, 60 glass stones (green, white, black) || [[Zendo (game)|Zendo]] (w/16 starter rule cards) & ICE-7 other games reference cards |rowspan=2| {{dts|2003}} |- | IceTowers boxed set || 2 alternate colors stashes & ''The Empty City'' book || IceTowers & ICE-7 reference cards |- | Icehouse Pieces monochrome stash tubes || gray stash || {{n/a|none}} |rowspan=2| {{dts|2006}} |- | Volcano Caps || 5 smalls grays || {{n/a|none}} |- !colspan=4| ===Treehouse=== |- | Treehouse Rainbow || one rainbow stash, a custom die |rowspan=2| [[Treehouse (game)|Treehouse]] |rowspan=2| {{dts|2006}} |- | Treehouse Xeno || one xeno stash, a custom die |- | ''3HOUSE'' booklet (3H) || {{n/a|none}} || Black Ice, [[Martian Chess]], Binary Homeworlds{{cite web|title=3HOUSE|url=http://wunderland.com/icehouse/3HOUSE/Index.html|website=Wunderland.com|publisher=Looney Labs|accessdate=June 10, 2015}} || {{dts|2007}} |- | Pink Treehouse || 1 pink stash || [[Treehouse (game)|Treehouse]] || {{dts|2008}} |- !colspan=4| ===Looney Pyramids=== |- | IceDice || 2 rainbow stashes, two custom dice || IceDice, Launchpad 23 || {{dts|2011|6}} |- | Treehouse (second edition) || one rainbow stash, a six-sided die and a custom die, a little fabric board || [[Treehouse (game)|Treehouse]], Pharaoh || {{dts|2011|9}} |- | Rainbow Stash box || one rainbow stash || {{n/a|none}} || |- | Xeno Stash box || one xeno stash || {{n/a|none}} || |- | Pink Hijinks || three pink trios, 3×3 grid and a custom die || Pink Hijinks || {{dts|2012|12}} |- | ''Pyramid Primer #1'' booklet (PP1) || {{n/a|none}} || 13 games: Black ICE, Caldera, Homeworlds, IceDice, Icehouse, IceTowers, Launchpad 23, Martian Chess, Martian Coasters, Pharaoh, Treehouse, World War 5, Zark City{{cite web |title=Guide to Looney Pyramids |url=http://www.looneylabs.com/guide-looney-pyramids |accessdate=June 20, 2018 |work=www.looneylabs.com |publisher=Looney Labs |language=en}} || |- |Pyramid Arcade (PA) |90 pyramids: 10 colors (rainbow & xeno) 3 trio each; 8 mini gameboards & 3 large boards; cards: Zark City (5 suited square deck), Twin Win cards, Pyramid Arcade cards; 9 six-sided dice: 3 standard, 3 lightning, 3 others; a drawstring bag, a turn token |22 games: Black Ice, Color Wheel, Give or Take, Hijinks, Homeworlds, Ice Dice, Ice Towers, Launchpad 23, Looney Ludo, Lunar Invaders, Martian Chess, Petal Battle, Petri Dish, Pharaoh, Powerhouse, Pyramid-Sham-Bo, Twin Win, Treehouse, Verticality, Volcano, World War 5, Zark City | {{dts|2016|11|3}} |} *standard colors: red, blue, green, yellow *Neon colors: purple, orange, lime green, and hot pink *alternate colors: [[cyan]], clear, white, purple *original monochrome stash tubes colors: red, yellow, blue, green, purple, orange, black, white, clear *rainbow colors: red, dark blue, green, yellow, opaque black (standard plus black) *xeno colors: orange, purple, cyan, clear, white ==Games== [[File:Zendo game.jpg|thumb|Icehouse pieces being used to play ''Zendo'']] As a game system, Icehouse pieces can be used to play many different abstract [[strategy game]]s. Most games need at least two colors, and some require other readily-available equipment such as glass stones or a [[checkerboard]]. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Game !! Year !! Publication !! Designer(s) !! description/note |- | ''[[Icehouse (game)|Icehouse]]'' || {{dts|1989}} || PwP, PP1 || Andrew Looney and John Cooper || |- | ''[[Martian Chess]]'' || {{dts|1999}} || MCS, PwP, 3H, PP1, PA || Andrew Looney|| |- | ''[[Zendo (game)|Zendo]]'' || 2001 || PwP || || Origins Award: ''Best Abstract Board Game of 2003'' |- | ''Homeworlds'' || 2001 || PwP, PP1, PA || || an abstract space battle/exploration game |- | ''Binary Homeworlds'' || 2007 || 3H || John Cooper || variant of Homeworlds |- |''[[IceTowers]]'' || 1999 || MCS, PwP, PP1, PA || Andrew Looney || a stacking game |- | ''IceTraders'' || 1999 || MCS || || an early version of Homeworlds |- |''Zarcana'' || 1999 || MCS || || |- |''Thin Ice'' || 2001 ||PwP || || |- |''Martian Backgammon'' || 2001 ||PwP || || |- |''Volcano'' || 2001 ||PwP, PA || || |- |''RAMbots'' || 2001 || PwP || || |- |''Pikemen'' || 2001 || PwP || || |- |''Zagami'' || 2001 || PwP || || |- |''Gnostica'' || 2001 || PwP || || |- |''Black ICE'' || 2007 || 3H, PP1, PA || || |- |''[[Treehouse (game)|Treehouse]]'' || 2006 || Treehouse, PP1, PA || || a [[matching game]]; Origins Award for ''Best Board Game of 2006'' |- |''IceDice'' || || PP1, IceDice, PA || || |- |''Launchpad 23'' || || PP1, IceDice, PA || || collecting game |- |''Pharaoh'' || || PP1, Treehouse 2nd Edition, PA || || |- |''Caldera'' || || PP1 || || |- |''Martian Coasters'' || || PP1 || || |- |''World War 5'' || || PP1, PA || || |- |''Zark City'' || || PP1, PA || || |- |''Pink Hijinks'' || {{dts|2012|12}} || Pink Hijinks || || "king of the hill" strategy |- |Color Wheel |rowspan=11| {{dts|2016|11|3}} |rowspan=11| PA || || |- |Give or Take || || |- |Hijinks || || |- |Looney Ludo || || |- |Lunar Invaders || || |- |Petal Battle || || |- |Petri Dish || || |- |Powerhouse || || |- |Pyramid-Sham-Bo || || |- |Twin Win || || |- | Verticality || || |} == Score-keeping == Icehouse pieces can also be used as a score-keeping device or [[counter (collectible card games)|counter]] for non-icehouse games. For example, when scoring a [[Cosmic Wimpout]] game, a small pyramid would be worth five points, a medium pyramid worth twenty-five points, and a large pyramid one-hundred; the goal being to collect five of the large pieces (for the 500 point standard game). They could be use instead of [[poker chip]]s, the denominations would be determined by size rather than color (smalls are worth one, mediums worth five, and larges valued at twenty-five, for example). == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{url|icehousegames.com|official website}} * {{url|icehousegames.org}} - Fan-run community website and comprehensive game listings *Board Game Geek pages ** [http://www.boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/Icehouse_pieces# Icehouse pieces] ** [http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgamefamily/20/looney-pyramids Looney Pyramids] - Board game family page * [http://www.looneylabs.com/guide-looney-pyramids Rules for 13 games] [[Category:Icehouse games| ]] [[Category:Origins Award winners]] [[Category:Game equipment]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/104.32.146.130|104.32.146.130]] ([[User talk:104.32.146.130|talk]]) to last revision by BoogerD. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox television | show_name = If I Can Dream | image = If I Can Dream (title card).jpg | rating = | picture_format = | company = [[19 Entertainment]] | distributor = [[CORE Media Group]] | creator = [[Simon Fuller]] | country = United States / United Kingdom | network = [[Hulu]], then traditional broadcast | first_aired = March 2, 2010 | last_aired = October 5, 2010 | num_seasons = 1 | num_episodes = 32 | website = http://www.ificandream.com }} '''''If I Can Dream''''' is a webseries that was created by [[Simon Fuller]]. The show was not renewed for a second season in 2011.
==Format== {{Quote box |quote= This isn’t reality TV. There’s no judges or voting off. There’s not a pot of money sitting at the end ... the goal is to get a job that will allow us to get out of the house and to move on to a bigger career. This is just the first step. |source=Kara Kilmer<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2010/03/02/american-idol-if-i-can-dream-justin-gaston/|title='American Idol' + 'Real World' = New Web series 'If I Can Dream'|date=March 2, 2010|publisher=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|author=Vlada Gelman|accessdate=March 4, 2010}}</ref> |width=30% |align=left }} The show followed performers who moved into a house in [[Hollywood]], [[California]]. The house was wired with 56 AXIS<ref name="NewTeeVee">{{Cite web|url=http://newteevee.com/2010/03/01/inside-the-if-i-can-dream-house-5-aspiring-dreamers-3-cdns-56-h-264-cameras/|title=Inside the If I Can Dream House: 5 Aspiring Dreamers, 3 CDNs, 56 H.264 Cameras|date=March 1, 2010|publisher=[[NewTeeVee]]|author=Liz Shannon Miller|accessdate=March 4, 2010}}</ref> cameras and the footage was broadcast live on the show's website. Each contestant was judged to excel in either one of the creative arts, sport or fashion and the premise of the show was to follow them as they attempted to succeed in their chosen field.<ref name="EW">{{Cite web|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2010/03/02/if-i-can-dream/|title='If I Can Dream': Miley Cyrus' ex and some other Hollywood hopefuls hit the web 24/7|date=March 2, 2010|publisher=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|author=Jennifer Armstrong|accessdate=March 4, 2010}}</ref><ref name="Variety">{{Cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118012882.html|title=Hulu, Fuller have a 'Dream'|date=December 16, 2009|publisher=''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''|author=Michael Schneider|accessdate=March 4, 2010}}</ref>
As of December 2009, the house was fully prepared and on March 2, 2010, the cast moved in. The television aspect of the show was weekly 30-minute highlight shows airing first through [[Hulu]]<ref name="tribune">{{Cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/sc-ent-0224-if-i-can-dream-20100302,0,979463.story|title=Hollywood wannabes get ‘Big Brother' treatment|date=March 2, 2010|publisher=''[[Chicago Tribune]]''|author=Alejandra Cancino|accessdate=March 4, 2010}}</ref> then later through a traditional broadcast network. [[Clear Channel]] was to handle radio aspects and [[MySpace]] was the production's online partner. [[PepsiCo]] and [[Ford Motor Company]] signed on to sponsor the project.<ref name="PRNewswire">{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/if-i-can-dream-set-for-launch-early-in-2010-79454392.html|title=If I Can Dream Set for Launch Early in 2010|publisher=[[PRNewswire]]|accessdate=March 4, 2010}}</ref> The first season concluded after 32 episodes . On October 4, 2010 the show's website said "Thanks for being a part of Season 1. Get ready for Season 2 starting in 2011."
===Technology=== [[File:If I Can Dream screenshot.png|thumb|The website's layout]] The ''If I Can Dream'' House was wired with 56 [[Axis Communications|AXIS]] Q1755 H.264 cameras delivering content across 3 CDNs (Akamai, [[BitGravity]] and [[Highwinds Network Group|Highwinds]]). Video feeds were available at both 500 kbit/s and 1 Mbit/s. As designed, ''If I Can Dream'' was the largest persistent live "event" produced by a media company.<ref name="NewTeeVee"/> Accompanying the technology platform was a website built by an interactive design firm.<ref name="WeCanDream">{{Cite web|url=http://pokenewyork.com/story/project-launch/we-can-dream/ |title=We Can Dream |date=January 20, 2010 |publisher=[[Poke New York]] |author=Poke New York |accessdate=March 5, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100227225135/http://pokenewyork.com/story/project-launch/we-can-dream |archivedate=February 27, 2010 }}</ref>
==Cast members==
===Dreamers===
====Original members==== When the show debuted on March 2, 2010, the original five members of the cast included: * Giglianne Braga<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://ificandream.com/#/dreamers/modal/bio/4| title=About Giglianne | accessdate=2010-06-25 | publisher=If I Can Dream}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| url=http://www.hulu.com/if-i-can-dream/giglianne | title=If I Can Dream: Giglianne | publisher=Hulu.com | accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref> {{IPAc-en|ˌ|dʒ|ɪ|ɡ|l|i|ˈ|ɑː|n|i}}: a 21-year-old aspiring high-fashion model from [[Kearny, New Jersey]]. Over the course of the first season, she partook in numerous photo shoots and appeared in three music videos. Giglianne posed nude for [[Marc Jacobs]] "Protect the Skin You're In" campaign and, along with Ben and Justin, [[PETA]]'s "I'd Rather Go Naked Than Wear Fur" campaign.<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://blog.peta.org/archives/2010/06/if_i_can_dream.php | title='If I Can Dream'...| accessdate=2010-06-22 | publisher=PETA}}</ref> * {{Interlanguage link multi|Ben Elliott (actor)|fr|3=Ben Elliott}}:<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://ificandream.com/#/dreamers/modal/bio/5 | title=About Ben | accessdate=2010-06-25 | publisher=If I Can Dream}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| url=http://www.hulu.com/if-i-can-dream/ben | title=If I Can Dream: Ben | publisher=Hulu.com | accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref><ref name="tvguide1">{{Cite web| url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Dream-Meet-Hot-1015654.aspx | title=If I Can Dream: Meet the Hot Blonde and the Heartthrob | date=2010-03-04 | accessdate=2010-06-25 | publisher=TV Guide | author=Natalie Abrams}}</ref> a 22-year-old aspiring actor from [[Hamburg (town), New York|Hamburg, New York]]. Over the course of the first season, he concentrated on acting lessons from Kirby and casting calls but also participated in promotional photo shoots for PETA and a music video. He currently later had a recurring role on the [[ABC Family]] series ''[[The Lying Game (TV series)|The Lying Game]]''. * [[Justin Gaston]]:<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://ificandream.com/#/dreamers/modal/bio/1 | title=About Justin | accessdate=2010-06-25 | publisher=If I Can Dream}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| url=http://www.hulu.com/if-i-can-dream/justin | title=If I Can Dream: Justin | publisher=Hulu.com | accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| url=http://oceanup.com/2010/03/03/justin-gaston-if-i-can-dream-cast-shoot | title=Justin Gaston If I Can Dream Cast SHOOT | date=2010-03-01 | accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref> a 21-year-old ''[[Nashville Star]]'' season six contestant from [[Pineville, Louisiana]] and an aspiring Country singer-songwriter. He is also a former underwear model, and he is known for having been the former boyfriend of [[Miley Cyrus]]. He also starred in country singer [[Taylor Swift]]'s "[[Love Story (Taylor Swift song)|Love Story]]" music video. Justin performed at [[Wango Tango]] and local venues over the course of his stay. He also participated in a promotional photo shoot for PETA. He also briefly opened for [[Kris Allen]]. * [[Kara Killmer]]:<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://ificandream.com/#/dreamers/modal/bio/3 | title=About Kara | accessdate=2010-06-25 | publisher=If I Can Dream}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.hulu.com/if-i-can-dream/kara | title=If I Can Dream: Kara | publisher=Hulu.com | accessdate=2010-06-25 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110905020832/http://www.hulu.com/if-i-can-dream/kara | archivedate=2011-09-05 | df= }}</ref> a 21-year-old aspiring actress from [[Crowley, Texas]]. Killmer is also a 2010 graduate of Baylor University in Waco, Texas; graduating with a major in Theater Arts.<ref name="ny-daily-news">{{Cite web| url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/2010/03/03/2010-03-03_if_i_can_dream_web_series_from_american_idol_creator_tracks_musicians_on_their_w.html | title='If I Can Dream' web series from 'American Idol' creator tracks musicians on their way to stardom | date=March 3, 2010 | publisher=[[NY Daily News]] | author=Gina Salamone | accessdate=March 4, 2010}}</ref> Over the course of the first season, Kara took extensive acting lessons from John Kirby, attended casting calls, and participated in several fund raisers via the [[Pepsi Refresh Project]]. * Amanda Phillips:<ref name="tvguide1" /><ref>{{Cite web| url=http://ificandream.com/#/dreamers/modal/bio/2 | title=About Amanda | accessdate=2010-06-25 | publisher=If I Can Dream}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| url=http://www.hulu.com/if-i-can-dream/amanda | title=If I Can Dream: Amanda | publisher=Hulu.com | accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref> a 23-year-old former [[National Football League Cheerleading|NFL cheerleader]] from [[Geneva, New York]] aspiring to be an actress or model. Over the course of her stay, Amanda took several acting lessons from Kirby, attended casting calls, and participated in photo shoots.
====Additions==== * [[Alex Lambert]]:<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://ificandream.com/#/dreamers/modal/bio/6 | title=About Alex | accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| url=http://www.hulu.com/if-i-can-dream/alex | title=If I Can Dream: Alex | publisher=Hulu.com | accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref> Joined the show on April 1, 2010.<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2010/04/02/american-idol-castoff-alex-lambert-if-i-can-dream-will-show-people-the-real-me/ | title='American Idol' Castoff Alex Lambert: 'If I Can Dream' Will Show People 'the real me' | date=2010-04-02 | accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref> Lambert is a 19-year-old former [[American Idol (season 9)|American Idol season 9]] semifinalist from [[North Richland Hills, Texas]], whose early elimination prompted a petition to get him back on the show.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/americanidoltracker/2010/03/alex-lambert-joins-if-i-can-dream-cast-loses-mullet-.html|title=Alex Lambert joins 'If I Can Dream' cast, loses mullet|date=March 30, 2010|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|author=Gina Shirley Halperin|accessdate=March 30, 2010}}</ref> Alex's song "Dream With My Eyes Open" replaced the Elvis Presley rendition of "If I Can Dream" as the show's theme song with Episode 11.<ref name="iicdyiyo">{{cite episode |title=You're In, You're Out |series=If I Can Dream | serieslink=If I Can Dream | airdate=2010-05-10 |season=1 |number=11 |network=[[Hulu]] |location=[[Los Angeles, California]]}}</ref> “I Didn’t Know”, a soulful pop song written by Lambert with Nasri Atweh and [[Adam Messinger]], was selected and made into a music video by [[Clear Channel]] and 19 Entertainment, and then released on July 26, 2010, through [[iheartradio]]<ref>[http://www.marketwatch.com/story/clear-channel-radio-creates-music-video-for-rising-star-alex-lambert-2010-07-26?reflink=MW_news_stmp "Clear Channel Radio Creates Music Video for Rising Star Alex Lambert"], 'MarketWatch', July 26, 2010.</ref> The [[Webby Awards|15th Annual Webby Awards]] selected Lambert's ’’I Didn’t Know’’ music video as an Official Webby Honoree in the Online Film & Video: Best Editing category.<ref>[http://www.webbyawards.com/webbys/current_honorees.php?media_id=97&category_id=145&season=15 "15th Annual Webby Awards Official Honoree Selections"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010222140/http://www.webbyawards.com/webbys/current_honorees.php?media_id=97&category_id=145&season=15 |date=2012-10-10 }}, 'The Webby Awards', April 12, 2011.</ref> On June 26, 2012, [[Trouble (Chris Rene song)|Trouble]], a song co-written by Alex Lambert and [[busbee]] was released on iTunes as [[The X Factor (U.S.)|X-Factor]] finalist [[Chris Rene]]'s second single.<ref>Parker, Lyndsey [http://music.yahoo.com/blogs/reality-rocks/chris-rene-finally-releases-song-collaborates-alex-lambert-223421277.html/1 "Chris Rene Finally Releases New Song, Collaborates with Alex Lambert'"], 'Reality Rocks', June 21, 2012.</ref> * [[Veronica Ballestrini]], an 18 year old participant and winner of the "MySpace Dream Break" contest. She visited the mansion for a weekend and went on a date with Ben.<ref name="iicdffbtm">{{cite episode |title=From First Base to MySpace |series=If I Can Dream | serieslink=If I Can Dream | airdate=2010-06-15 |season=1 |number=16 |network=[[Hulu]] |location=[[Los Angeles, California]]}}</ref> A couple of weeks after her visit, Michael Herwick asked her to move into the mansion.<ref name="iicdwwahe" /> During her time at the mansion she recorded her song "Fascinated" co-written with David Kopatz and developed a romantic relationship with Alex Lambert..
====Departures==== * Amanda Phillips: Couldn't deal with the lack of privacy inherent to the project. As a result, she decided to leave the show on May 8, 2010.<ref name="iicdyiyo" /><ref>{{Cite web| url=https://twitter.com/amanda_phill/status/13591896662 | title=Twitter / Amanda Phillips | accessdate=2010-06-25 | date=2010-05-08}}</ref> * Justin Gaston: Justin moved out of the house on June 24, 2010.<ref>{{Cite web| url=https://twitter.com/ificandream/status/17039547185 | title=Twitter / If I Can Dream | date=2010-06-24 | accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref> His departure was a "graduation" as he joined ''[[American Idol]]'' winner [[Kris Allen]] as a temporary opening act on tour.<ref name="iicdwwahe">{{cite episode |title=Who Wants a Happy Ending? |series=If I Can Dream | serieslink=If I Can Dream | airdate=2010-06-29 |season=1 |number=18 |network=[[Hulu]] |location=[[Los Angeles, California]]}}</ref> He is currently writing in Nashville.
===Additional talent=== In addition to the Dreamers, the series regularly features appearances by Hollywood actors, musicians, producers, acting coaches, agents and more. * John Kirby, brother of the late actor [[Bruno Kirby]], is a renowned acting coach, having taught such talent as [[Cameron Diaz]]<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,301520,00.html | title=A MODEL STUDENT | publisher=Entertainment Weekly | date=1994-03-25 | accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref> and [[Jim Caviezel]]<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://www.pressreleasepoint.com/renowned-acting-coaches-john-kirby-and-walter-pridgen-instruct-eastern-sky-theatre-company-acting-wo | title=Renowned Acting Coaches John Kirby and Walter Pridgen to Instruct Eastern Sky Theatre Company Acting Workshops | publisher=PressReleasePoint | date=2009-04-13 | accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref> among others. He makes regular appearances on the series giving acting lessons to Kara and Ben. He has also given lessons to Giglianne and formerly instructed Amanda. * Michael Herwick is the executive producer of the show. Making regular appearances, he helps guide the Dreamers with his connections in the fashion, photography, music, and acting professions. * Caitlin Levin is featured as the house chef. She provides cooking lessons and recipes to the live stream viewers. * Lindsay Jones is featured in the beginning of the series as the house chef. She provides cooking lessons, plans themed dinners and shares recipes to the live stream viewers. Her recipes can be found on FoodFlirt.com. * LeeAnn Smith Weintraub, MPH, RD, visited the house to provide nutrition counseling and diet advice. * Jordyn Mallory, participant and winner of the second "MySpace Dream Break" contest.<ref>http://www.hulu.com/watch/178653/if-i-can-dream-myspace-winner-jordyn-mallory-visits-the-dream-house</ref> Mallory moved into the house for a period of two weeks during which she received complementary vocal, guitar, and piano lessons, as well as the opportunity to write and demo a song written with David Kopatz. * [[Brandon W Jones|Brandon Jones]] is featured as the house pool technician. He interacts with all the Dreamers, sometimes playing guitar and singing with [[Justin Gaston]] and [[Alex Lambert]].
==See also== * [[19 Entertainment]] * [[CKX, Inc.]] * ''[[American Idol]]''
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.ificandream.com/}} * {{IMDb title|1658997}} * [http://www.hulu.com/if-i-can-dream ''If I Can Dream''] at [[Hulu]]

page.title: Lady Gaga and the Muppets Holiday Spectacular

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/2600:1:9A77:4038:CD3F:D58F:D4CA:97CA|2600:1:9A77:4038:CD3F:D58F:D4CA:97CA]] ([[User talk:2600:1:9A77:4038:CD3F:D58F:D4CA:97CA|talk]]) to last version by MagicatthemovieS
revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Lady Gaga and the Muppets Holiday Spectacular | image = Lady Gaga and the Muppets' Holiday Spectacular.png | caption = Title card | director = Gregg Gelfand | presenter = [[Tom Kane]] | starring = [[Lady Gaga]]
[[The Muppets]] | country = United States | language = English | executive_producer = Salli Frattini | producer = Eric Conte | editor = | runtime = 90 minutes | company = [[The Muppets Studio]] | channel = [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] | distributor = [[Disney-ABC Domestic Television]] | first_aired = {{start date|2013|11|28}} }} '''''Lady Gaga and the Muppets Holiday Spectacular''''' is a [[List of Thanksgiving television specials|Thanksgiving television special]] with American singer [[Lady Gaga]] and [[the Muppets]]. The 90-minute program aired on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] on November 28, 2013, with guest stars [[Joseph Gordon-Levitt]], [[Elton John]] and [[RuPaul]] and an appearance by [[Kristen Bell]]. It was the second Gaga Thanksgiving special on ABC, after ''[[A Very Gaga Thanksgiving]]'' in 2011. The singer had previously collaborated with the Muppets on media appearances and in her shows. The special featured songs from Gaga's third [[studio album]], ''[[Artpop]]'', and duets with the guest stars. Critics gave the special mixed reviews, with some praising Gaga for being relatable in the show. Other reviewers were disappointed with its lack of production ideas, other than as a promotion for ''Artpop''. It had lower [[Nielsen ratings|ratings]] than other Thanksgiving specials, with a total of 3.62 million viewers and a 0.9 rating in the adult age 18–49 demographic. ==Synopsis== Announcer [[Tom Kane]] explains to [[Pepe the King Prawn]] that the special is being filmed for [[Lady Gaga]], the latter then appears and explains why she invited the Muppets and then performs "[[Venus (Lady Gaga song)|Venus]]". After [[Statler and Waldorf]]'s review of the performance, [[Kristen Bell]] asks for Gaga's autograph. This annoys [[Miss Piggy]] who was planning her own finale and enlists the Muppets to hold auditions. Gaga performs "[[Applause (Lady Gaga song)|Applause]]", followed by "[[Bennie and the Jets]]" and "[[Artpop (song)|Artpop]]" with [[Elton John]] (with the Muppets joining them for the latter). After discussing ideas for the finale, Gaga performs "Manicure" and the Muppets talk about the most inappropriate gifts they ever received. [[Kermit the Frog]] joins Gaga in a duet of "[[Gypsy (Lady Gaga song)|Gypsy]]", and [[Joseph Gordon-Levitt]] duets on "[[Baby, It's Cold Outside]]". Kermit's friendship with Gaga angers Miss Piggy; after a performance of "Fashion!" by Gaga and [[RuPaul]], Miss Piggy bemoans the attention paid to the singer. Although she dreams of singing "[[Santa Baby]]", she is upstaged in her dream by [[Youthful Praise]]. After a trailer for the upcoming ''[[Muppets Most Wanted]]'', Gaga asks Miss Piggy to suggest a finale and reprises "Applause" with the Muppets. ==Production== [[File:Lady GaGa at 2009 MTV VMA's.jpg|thumb|left|upright|alt=Lady Gaga, holding a trophy|Gaga at the [[2009 MTV Video Music Awards]], where [[Kermit the Frog]] was her date]] In October 2013, the [[American Broadcasting Company]] (ABC) announced a 90-minute special entitled ''Lady Gaga and the Muppets' Holiday Spectacular''. It was the second [[List of Thanksgiving television specials|Thanksgiving television special]] on ABC by Gaga, after ''[[A Very Gaga Thanksgiving]]'' in 2011. The singer collaborated with the Muppets for the special, which aired on November 28, 2013. "I was so excited when ABC called me about doing a holiday special this year. I knew it just wouldn't be a complete night of laughter and memories without the Muppets! Can't wait to see the gang again, and I hope Miss Piggy's still not mad about Kermit ... We're just friends," Gaga said about the special.{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/lady-gaga-teams-muppets-adorable-photos-result/story?id=20603044|title=Lady Gaga Teams Up With the Muppets and Adorable Photos Result|last=Messer|first=Lesley|date=October 17, 2013|publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company]]|accessdate=December 14, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140318120644/http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/lady-gaga-teams-muppets-adorable-photos-result/story?id=20603044|archivedate=March 18, 2014|df=mdy-all}} Guest stars included [[Joseph Gordon-Levitt]], [[Elton John]] and [[RuPaul]], with an appearance by [[Kristen Bell]].{{Cite journal|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2013/10/17/lady-gaga-muppets-holiday-spectacular|title=Lady Gaga teams up with her littlest monsters, the Muppets, for another holiday spectacular|first=Jodi|last=Walker|accessdate=November 15, 2013|date=October 17, 2013|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]}} Gaga performed several songs from her third studio album, ''[[Artpop]]''.{{Cite journal|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/lady-gaga-to-celebrate-thanksgiving-with-the-muppets-20131018|title=Lady Gaga to Celebrate Thanksgiving With the Muppets|accessdate=November 15, 2013|date=October 18, 2013|first=Kory|last=Grow|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028043301/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/lady-gaga-to-celebrate-thanksgiving-with-the-muppets-20131018|archivedate=October 28, 2013|df=mdy-all}} The singer had collaborated twice with the Muppets in the past; in 2009 Kermit the Frog was her date at the [[2009 MTV Video Music Awards]], and she featured [[Jim Henson's Creature Shop]] pieces on [[the Monster Ball Tour]] (2009–2011).{{cite journal|last=Marechal|first=AJ|title=ABC Sets Holiday Special with Lady Gaga and the Muppets|url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/abc-sets-holiday-special-with-lady-gaga-and-the-muppets-1200735249/|accessdate=October 17, 2013|magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=October 17, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017223449/http://variety.com/2013/tv/news/abc-sets-holiday-special-with-lady-gaga-and-the-muppets-1200735249/|archivedate=October 17, 2013|df=mdy-all}} The special was described in press releases as "an avant-garde twist on the classic holiday variety show as Lady Gaga goes backstage with the Muppets, making a performance dream come true for the multi-platinum singer-songwriter when they combine forces to sing holiday favorites and Lady Gaga hits". It was confirmed that holiday classics like "[[Deck the Halls]]" and "[[Jingle Bells]]" would be performed by the Muppets, as well as songs from ''Artpop''. A promotional tie-in with the special was the trailer for ''Muppets Most Wanted'', in which Gaga made a cameo appearance.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/oct/17/entertainment/la-et-ms-lady-gaga-muppets-holiday-special-20131017|title=Lady Gaga teams with the Muppets for unnecessary ABC holiday special|last=Kennedy|first=Gerrick D.|date=October 17, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2016|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221104150/http://articles.latimes.com/2013/nov/29/entertainment/la-et-ms-lady-gaga-and-the-muppets-created-a-holiday-tease-20131129|archivedate=December 21, 2016|df=mdy-all}} Kory Grow of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' called the special a "fitting move" for the singer, since she was releasing ''Artpop'' and the Muppets frequently collaborated with celebrities. The special was acquired by [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]] in the United Kingdom, with Dayna Donaldson of the network describing it as "a high energy and truly unique musical show full of fun".{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/uks-channel-5-snaps-up-660068|title=U.K.'s Channel 5 Snaps Up ABC's 'Lady Gaga & the Muppets' Holiday Spectacular'|last=Kemp|first=Stuart|date=November 26, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2016|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221083111/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/uks-channel-5-snaps-up-660068|archivedate=December 21, 2016|df=mdy-all}} After its broadcast, it was obtained by [[Netflix|Netflix Canada]] for 13 months of [[streaming media|streaming]].{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2013/12/06/netflix-canada-lady-gaga-muppets_n_4398143.html|title=Netflix Canada To Stream 'Lady Gaga & The Muppets Holiday Spectacular'|last=Jancelewicz|first=Chris|date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2016|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221104150/http://articles.latimes.com/2013/nov/29/entertainment/la-et-ms-lady-gaga-and-the-muppets-created-a-holiday-tease-20131129|archivedate=December 21, 2016|df=mdy-all}} Previews of the show, uploaded on Gaga's [[Instagram]] account, showed the singer performing "Applause"{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/lady-gaga-sings-applause-with-the-muppets/|title=Lady Gaga sings "Applause" with the Muppets|last=Derschowitz|first=Jessica|date=November 27, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2016|publisher=[[CBS News]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221104150/http://articles.latimes.com/2013/nov/29/entertainment/la-et-ms-lady-gaga-and-the-muppets-created-a-holiday-tease-20131129|archivedate=December 21, 2016|df=mdy-all}} and planning a party for the special's finale.{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1717428/lady-gaga-muppets-thanksgiving-special/|title=Lady Gaga (And Chickens) May Make Muppet History|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|date=November 14, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2016|publisher=[[MTV News]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150601182452/http://www.mtv.com/news/1717428/lady-gaga-muppets-thanksgiving-special/|archivedate=June 1, 2015|df=mdy-all}} {{clear}} ==Reception== ===Ratings=== {{multiple image | footer = Special guests included [[Joseph Gordon-Levitt]], [[Elton John]], [[RuPaul]], and [[Kristen Bell]] | width = | image1 = Joseph Gordon-Levitt 2013.jpg | width1 = {{#expr: (120 * 2267 / 2872) round 0}} | alt1 = Joseph Gordon-Levitt, wearing a tuxedo | image2 = Elton John 2011 Shankbone 2.JPG | width2 = {{#expr: (143 * 2278 / 2848) round 0}} | alt2 = Elton John, with tinted glasses | image3 = RuPaul by David Shankbone.jpg | width3 = {{#expr: (158 * 1097 / 1371) round 0}} | alt3 = RuPaul, speaking into a microphone | image4 = Kristen Bell Frozen premiere 2013 (cropped).jpg | width4 = {{#expr: (126 * 1863/ 2418) round 0}} | alt4 = Kristen Bell, smiling }} The special had 3.62 million viewers and a 0.9 [[Audience_measurement#Ratings_point|rating]] in the adult age 18-49 demographic. Its rating was lower than ''A Very Gaga Thanksgiving'', which had a 1.6 rating in the same demographic and 5.4 million viewers.{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/486135/lady-gaga-and-the-muppets-fail-to-bring-in-ratings-with-thanksgiving-special-on-abc|title=Lady Gaga and the Muppets Fail to Bring in Ratings With Thanksgiving Special on ABC|publisher=[[E!]]|first=Tierney|last=Bricker|date=November 30, 2013|accessdate=December 15, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161222073745/http://www.eonline.com/news/486135/lady-gaga-and-the-muppets-fail-to-bring-in-ratings-with-thanksgiving-special-on-abc|archivedate=December 22, 2016|df=mdy-all}} The total rating was the same as ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'', which was concurrently broadcast on Fox. It was down by 25% than the 2012 Thanksgiving special, ''Bad 25''.{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/sdsdskdh279882992z1/tv-ratings-thursday-glee-ties-lady-gaga-and-the-muppets-holiday-spectacular-as-football-wins-thanksgiving/|title=TV Ratings Thursday: 'Glee' Ties 'Lady Gaga and the Muppets Holiday Spectacular' as Football Wins Thanksgiving|publisher=[[Screener (website)|Zap2it]]|date=November 29, 2013|accessdate=November 29, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220165310/http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/sdsdskdh279882992z1/tv-ratings-thursday-glee-ties-lady-gaga-and-the-muppets-holiday-spectacular-as-football-wins-thanksgiving/|archivedate=December 20, 2016|df=mdy-all}} The rating was adjusted to 1.0 by [[Nielsen ratings]].{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/sdsdskdh279882992z1/thursday-final-ratings-lady-gaga-and-the-muppets-holiday-spectacular-adjusted-up/|title=Thursday Final Ratings: 'Lady Gaga and the Muppets Holiday Spectacular' Adjusted U|publisher=Zap2it|date=December 3, 2013|accessdate=December 15, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220165233/http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/sdsdskdh279882992z1/thursday-final-ratings-lady-gaga-and-the-muppets-holiday-spectacular-adjusted-up/|archivedate=December 20, 2016|df=mdy-all}} In comparison, ABC's annual telecast of ''[[A Charlie Brown Thanksgiving]]'' before Gaga's special was watched by 5.4 million viewers and had a 1.6 rating in the 18–49 demographic.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/30/lady-gaga-muppet-ratings-thanksgiving_n_4364050.html|title=Lady Gaga's Muppet Thanksgiving Special Flopped Majorly In The Ratings|work=The Huffington Post|date=December 2, 2013|accessdate=December 15, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220173145/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/30/lady-gaga-muppet-ratings-thanksgiving_n_4364050.html|archivedate=December 20, 2016|df=mdy-all}} ===Critical response=== According to Marissa G. Muller of ''Rolling Stone'', Gaga "was at her most accessible during the show, sharing the difficulties of life on the road and her love of the holidays – specifically, how she grew up watching the Muppets and has had a long love for Kermit. The whole affair was relatively conservative for Gaga and weirdly progressive for the Muppets". Muller wrote that the special was aired at an opportune moment for Gaga, since ''Artpop''{{'s}} sales had dropped 82 percent in its second week and the show was hoped to woo back her audience. She called the opening performance of "Venus" one of its top moments.{{Cite journal|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/tv/news/five-memorable-moments-from-lady-gagas-muppets-holiday-spectacular-20131129|title=Five Memorable Moments From Lady Gaga's Muppets 'Holiday Spectacular'|accessdate=December 14, 2016|date=November 29, 2013|first=Marissa G.|last=Muller|work=Rolling Stone|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924191323/http://www.rollingstone.com/tv/news/five-memorable-moments-from-lady-gagas-muppets-holiday-spectacular-20131129|archivedate=September 24, 2016|df=mdy-all}} Mark Graham wrote for [[VH1]] that Gaga had a lack of relatability at that point in her career: "To her credit, [she] seems to have recognized this flaw in her brand strategy and has been working overtime of late to humanize herself ... [Anyone] who watches the cable premiere of ''Lady Gaga & The Muppets Holiday Spectacular'' ... will definitely gain a new appreciation for [her]".{{Cite journal|url=http://www.vh1.com/news/52092/lady-gaga-muppets/|title=Five Memorable Moments From Lady Gaga & The Muppets' Holiday Spectacular|accessdate=December 14, 2016|date=November 29, 2013|first=Mark|last=Graham|publisher=[[VH1]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220200321/http://www.vh1.com/news/52092/lady-gaga-muppets/|archivedate=December 20, 2016|df=mdy-all}} Maricela Gonzalez of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' called ''Lady Gaga and the Muppets' Holiday Spectacular'' a "cross-promotional commercial", enabling Gaga to promote ''Artpop'' and enhancing the Muppets' popularity. Gonzalez described it as "equal parts warm, fuzzy, cynical, and depressed by consumerism overtaking the so-called 'holiday spirit'. But why fret? It’s Lady Gaga and the Muppets!"{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2013/11/29/lady-gaga-muppets-holiday-spectacular-react|title='Lady Gaga & the Muppets' Holiday Spectacular' react: Cross-promotional cheer for one and all|work=Entertainment Weekly|first=Marcela|last=Gonzalez|date=November 29, 2013|accessdate=November 29, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221104150/http://articles.latimes.com/2013/nov/29/entertainment/la-et-ms-lady-gaga-and-the-muppets-created-a-holiday-tease-20131129|archivedate=December 21, 2016|df=mdy-all}} Myles McNutt of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' gave the special a grade of C, criticizing it as a mere promotional vehicle for Gaga with the Muppets feeling like a last-minute addition. The production was unable to balance Gaga's album promotion with a Muppets holiday special: "Nothing in ''Lady Gaga & The Muppets' Holiday Spectacular'' destroys the sanctity of the Muppets ... However, the potential for a Muppets holiday special was never given room to materialize amidst a Lady Gaga concert special designed to sell her new album. The choice to combine the two may have reached out to a broader audience, but the incongruence of the special's various parts ... was bound to frustrate a sizable portion of that audience."{{Cite journal|url=http://www.avclub.com/review/lady-gaga-and-the-muppets-holiday-spectacular-106088|title=Lady Gaga And The Muppets' Holiday Spectacular|accessdate=December 14, 2016|date=November 29, 2013|first=Myles|last=McNutt|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214185427/http://www.avclub.com/review/lady-gaga-and-the-muppets-holiday-spectacular-106088|archivedate=December 14, 2013|df=mdy-all}} Todd Martens of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' agreed, criticizing the special's commercial nature; he also said its songs were "less fit for a Muppet-like music special, and no one seemed willing to stray too far from the show's message of selling a product. Rather than aim for holiday timelessness, this was self-promotion, with the Muppets often coming to Gaga's world than the other way around."{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/nov/29/entertainment/la-et-ms-lady-gaga-and-the-muppets-created-a-holiday-tease-20131129|title=Lady Gaga and the Muppets create a holiday tease|last=Martens|first=Todd|date=November 29, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2016|work=Los Angeles Times|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221104150/http://articles.latimes.com/2013/nov/29/entertainment/la-et-ms-lady-gaga-and-the-muppets-created-a-holiday-tease-20131129|archivedate=December 21, 2016|df=mdy-all}} ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''{{'}}s Chris Willman also gave it a negative review, citing the show's palpably-low budget and its dialogue, guest appearances, Gaga's lip-syncing and production: "If the 90 seemingly endless minutes of ''Lady Gaga and the Muppets Holiday Spectacular'' had a predecessor, it might be the long-suppressed ''[[Star Wars Holiday Special|Star Wars Christmas Special]]'', though nothing here was so outrageously wrong (or right) that people will still be bootlegging this one in 35 years’ time. At least there was a familiar 'why is this happening?' question hovering over the star-crossed proceedings, albeit without the benefit of any guest stars as seriously wacky as that one's to show up and redeem the incongruousness. We knew [[Bea Arthur]] - we were friends with Bea Arthur - [[Senator, you're no Jack Kennedy|and RuPaul, you're no Bea Arthur]]."{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5812234/lady-gaga-recruits-elton-john-rupaul-for-muppets-thanksgiving-special|title=Lady Gaga Recruits Elton John, RuPaul for Muppets Thanksgiving Special|last=Willman|first=Chris|date=November 29, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2016|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219101954/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5812234/lady-gaga-recruits-elton-john-rupaul-for-muppets-thanksgiving-special|archivedate=February 19, 2014|df=mdy-all}} ==Personnel== Credits adapted from the special itself.{{cite AV media notes |title=Lady Gaga and the Muppets Holiday Spectacular |title-link= |others= Lady Gaga|year=2013 |type= Thanksgiving special|publisher=[[Disney-ABC Domestic Television]]|id= [[The Muppets Studio]]|location= |ref=}} * [[Lady Gaga]] as herself * [[Tom Kane]] as the Announcer ===Muppet performers=== {{main|List of Muppets}} * [[Steve Whitmire]] as [[Kermit the Frog]], [[Beaker (Muppet)|Beaker]], [[Rizzo the Rat]], [[Statler and Waldorf|Statler]] and [[Dr. Teeth and The Electric Mayhem#Lips|Lips]] * [[Eric Jacobson]] as [[Miss Piggy]], [[Fozzie Bear]], [[Animal (Muppet)|Animal]] and [[Sam Eagle]] * [[Dave Goelz]] as [[Gonzo (Muppet)|The Great Gonzo]], [[Bunsen Honeydew]], [[Statler and Waldorf|Waldorf]], [[Dr. Teeth and The Electric Mayhem#Zoot|Zoot]] and Albert the Rabbit * [[Bill Barretta]] as [[Rowlf the Dog]], [[Dr. Teeth and The Electric Mayhem#Dr. Teeth|Dr. Teeth]], [[Swedish Chef]], [[Pepe the King Prawn]], [[List of Muppets#Bobo the Bear|Bobo the Bear]] and Big Mean Carl * [[David Rudman]] as [[Scooter (Muppet)|Scooter]] and [[Dr. Teeth and The Electric Mayhem#Janice|Janice]] * [[Matt Vogel (puppeteer)|Matt Vogel]] as [[List of Muppets#Camilla the Chicken|Camilla the Chicken]], [[Dr. Teeth and The Electric Mayhem#Floyd Pepper|Floyd Pepper]], [[List of Muppets#Lew Zealand|Lew Zealand]] and Norman the Sheep * [[Peter Linz]] as [[Walter (Muppet)|Walter]] ==={{anchor|Special guest appearances}}Guest appearances=== * [[Kristen Bell]] as herself * [[Joseph Gordon-Levitt]] as himself * [[Elton John]] as himself * [[RuPaul]] as himself * [[Youthful Praise]] as themselves ==See also== {{Wikipedia books|Artpop}} * [[List of Thanksgiving television specials]] {{Clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Portal|Television in the United States}} * {{IMDB title|tt3268828}} {{Lady Gaga}} {{The Muppets}} [[Category:2010s American television specials]] [[Category:2013 television specials]] [[Category:American Broadcasting Company television specials]] [[Category:Disney television specials]] [[Category:Lady Gaga]] [[Category:Thanksgiving television specials]] [[Category:The Muppets television specials]] [[Category:Variety shows]]

{{unreferenced|date=January 2016}} [[File:Flag of Tajikistan.svg|thumb|right|200px]] The Tajik film industry produced ten feature films in [[2014 in film|2014]]. This article fully lists all non-pornographic films, including short films, that had a release date in that year and which were at least partly made by [[Tajikistan]]. It does not include films first released in previous years that had release dates in 2014.
Also included is an overview of the major events in Tajik film, including film festivals and awards ceremonies, as well as lists of those films that have been particularly well received, both critically and financially. ==Minor releases== {| class="wikitable" |+ "align=bottom" | |- style="background:#b0e0e6; text-align:center;" ! style="width:25%;"| Title ! style="width:25%;"| Director ! style="width:30%;"| Release Date ! style="width:10%;"| Genre |- |''After the Curtain'' || Emelie Coleman Mahdavian || || [[Documentary film|Documentary]] |- |''Emergency in Tajikistan'' || Jerry Aylmer || || [[Documentary film|Documentary]] |- |''Gilding'' || Ulugbek Sadykov || 4 December 2014 (Indonesia) || [[Drama film|Drama]] |- |''Mirror Without Reflection'' || Nosir Saidov || 1 February 2014 (Iran) || [[Drama film|Drama]] |- |''Rustam Casanova'' || Lorenzo Cioffi || || [[Documentary film|Documentary]] |- |''Silk Road Ghosts'' || Stephen Fenech || 4 September 2014 (Canada) || [[Documentary film|Documentary]] |- |''Tajik Rugby Quest'' || Faramarz Beheshti || || [[Documentary film|Documentary]] |- |''Tasfiya'' || Sharofat Arabova || || [[Fantasy film|Fantasy]] |- |''The Maestro of Mongolia'' || Jerry Aylmer || 13 September 2014 (UK) || [[Documentary film|Documentary]] |- |''The Teacher'' || Nosir Saidov || 16 September 2014 (Tajikistan) || [[Drama film|Drama]] |- |} ==See also== * [[2014 in film]] * [[Cinema of Tajikistan]] * [[List of Tajik submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{imdb country year|CODE|2014}} {{2014 films}} {{Films by country}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tajik Films of 2014}} [[Category:Lists of 2014 films by country or language|Tajik]] [[Category:2014 in Tajikistan|Films]] [[Category:Cinema of Tajikistan]] [[Category:Tajikistani films]] [[Category:Lists of films by country of production|Tajikistan]]

page.title: List of highest-grossing films in the United Kingdom

revision.comment: /* Highest-grossing films by box-office revenue */ Update
revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=January 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} [[File:Poster - Gone With the Wind 01.jpg|thumb|upright=1|right|''Gone with the Wind'' has generated the most admissions at cinemas in the United Kingdom|alt=The theatrical poster for Gone with the Wind.]] This list charts the most successful films at [[Movie theater|cinemas]] in the United Kingdom by [[box office]] sales, in [[pounds sterling]] and admissions. An overview of the top-earning films and record-holders is provided, as well as the highest-grossing British productions, the most successful non-English language films and the sound films that have generated the most admissions. A summary of the most popular films over the course of the last century is also included. American productions dominate, with all films earning over £50 million at the box office either completely or partly produced by [[Cinema of the United States|Hollywood]] studios. [[Cinema of the United Kingdom|British film]] is well represented, with about half the films on the list qualifying as British productions; however, due to the globalization of the film industry most successful British productions since the start of the [[twenty-first century]] have been co-produced with other countries. While there is no universally accepted definition of a film's nationality, a legal definition for the Britishness of a film has existed in English law since 2007, and this is the criteria used here. For films made prior to 2007, the nationalities listed by the sources supplying the data are used where they are given. The 2015 ''[[Star Wars]]'' film, ''[[Star Wars: The Force Awakens|The Force Awakens]]'', is the highest-grossing film in terms of [[Real versus nominal value (economics)|nominal]] box-office sales. The effects of [[inflation]] are a significant contributing factor to recent films surpassing the box-office records of older films, so when considering the number of admissions ''[[Gone with the Wind (film)|Gone with the Wind]]'' (1940) is the most successful film, although this was achieved over several release cycles prior to the [[home video]] era. ==Highest-grossing films by box-office revenue== ===Top earning films=== The highest earners at the box-office are mostly American films and UK-US co-productions. [[Film series]] dominate—accounting for twenty-eight of the thirty-three films that have earned in excess of £50 million—including six films in the [[Harry Potter (film series)|''Harry Potter'']] franchise, [[Peter Jackson]]'s first four [[Middle earth in film#Peter Jackson film series|Tolkien adaptations]], the four [[James Bond filmography#Daniel Craig: 2005–present|Daniel Craig ''James Bond'' films]] and four ''[[Star Wars]]'' instalments. Twenty entries are British co-productions and a further four are based on stories and characters created by British writers. This table only charts films released since 1989, but due to [[inflation]] it is unlikely anything released prior to then will surpass the films on the list in [[Real versus nominal value (economics)|nominal]] terms. {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |+Films with earnings over £50 million since 1989''Films that have grossed over £50 million'' :*Top films as of 2011: {{cite book |title=BFI Statistical Yearbook |year=2012 |publisher=[[British Film Institute]] |page=[http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-statistical-yearbook-2012.pdf#page=29 27]}} :*Top films in 2012: {{cite book |title=BFI Statistical Yearbook |year=2013 |publisher=British Film Institute |page=[http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-statistical-yearbook-2013.pdf#page=24 24]}} :*Top films in 2013: {{cite book |title=BFI Statistical Yearbook |year=2014 |publisher=British Film Institute |page=[http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-statistical-yearbook-2014.pdf#page=22 22]}} :*{{cite web |title=Top films in 2014 |publisher=British
