{{legend|#b6fcb6|size=100%|text={{†|alt=film currently playing}}|indicates the film's gross has increased since 19 February 2017.}}'' |} ===Record-holders=== Since 1975, twelve films may have set the record as the "highest-grossing" film. Regular tracking of box-office performance only started in 1975, so it is only possible to chart the transition of the record with any serious degree of accuracy within this period. Prior to then, ''[[The Sound of Music (film)|The Sound of Music]]'' is accepted to be the record-holder, assuming the record from another musical, ''[[South Pacific (1958 film)|South Pacific]]'', in 1966 and going on to treble the earnings of that film.{{cite book |last=Hall |first=Sheldon |chapter=The Sound of Music |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=19mmZIqaqhgC&pg=PA26 26]–28|editor-last1=Williams |editor-first1=Linda Ruth |editor-last2=Hammond |editor-first2=Michael |title=Contemporary American Cinema |year=2006 |publisher=[[McGraw-Hill]] |isbn=9780335218318 |quote=In Britain it opened in March 1965 and remained in continuous circulation until 1969. By December 1965, when it had been shown in only seventeen pre-release engagements in London and key cities, it had grossed £1,925,869 from 6,926,825 admissions [''Kine. Weekly'', 16 December 1965: 151]. A year later it had broken ''South Pacific'''s record of £2,300,000, which had been amassed over seven years of release, for the highest gross received by any film shown in Britain, with an estimated 21 million admissions to date ... As a result, it was named by ''Kine. Weekly'' top UK money-maker for four years in succession, from 1965 to 1968.}}{{cite book |last1=Hall |first1=Sheldon |last2=Neale |first2=Stephen |title=Epics, spectacles, and blockbusters: a Hollywood history |year=2010 |publisher=[[Wayne State University Press]] |isbn=978-0-8143-3008-1 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=jhvrSwOOsRgC&pg=PA184 184]–[https://books.google.com/books?id=Ro0hASPfC68C&pg=PA185 185] |quote=Estimates of worldwide rentals by the time of its withdrawal in 1969 ranged from $115 million to $125 million, either way making it the highest-grossing film to date. As much as $50 million of the total came from the foreign market, around half of it from Britain alone, where the film more than tripled the take of the previous all-time record-holder, ''South Pacific''.}} It is possible that some of the earlier films in the chart did not surpass the box office of ''The Sound of Music'', and it may have retained the record until the release of ''E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial''.{{refn |group=nb |name=som |It is not known exactly how much ''The Sound of Music'' grossed at the box office, since accurate records were not maintained at the time. Hall and Neale (2010) states that the "foreign" [[gross rental|rentals]] (the distributor's share of the box office outside of the US market after deducting the exhibitor's cut) were as high as $50 million, with approximately half coming from Britain alone. The film was the top money-maker of the year for four consecutive years between 1965 and 1968, during which time the [[US dollar]] to [[pound sterling]] [[exchange rate]] was approximately $2.68 to £1 averaged over the four years,{{cite web |first=Lawrence H. |last=Officer |title=Dollar-Pound Exchange Rate From 1791: 1965–1968 |publisher=[[MeasuringWorth]] |url=http://www.measuringworth.com/datasets/exchangepound/result.php?year_source=1965&year_result=1968 |accessdate=5 December 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131209221325/http://www.measuringworth.com/datasets/exchangepound/result.php?year_source=1965&year_result=1968# |archive-date=9 December 2013 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} meaning $25 million would translate to roughly £9.3 million. This estimate is consistent with [[Roger Manvell]]'s (the first director of the [[British Film Academy]]), who estimated its earnings as of 1968 at over £7 million.{{cite book |last=Manvell |first=Roger |authorlink=Roger Manvell |title=New cinema in the U.S.A.: the feature film since 1946 |year=1968 |series=Picturebacks Series |publisher=Studio Vista |page=[https://books.google.com/books?ei=viOdUomrFILb7Abyw4HADw&id=OI5ZAAAAMAAJ&q=%22sound+of+music%22+%22%C2%A37+million%22 28] |quote=''The Sound of Music'' was seen by some 23 million people in Britain, and grossed more than £7 million in that country alone.}} [[20th Century Fox]] collected roughly two-thirds of the gross,{{cite news |first=Joan |last=Barthel |title='The Sound of Music': Biggest Money-Making Movie of All Time — How Come? |date=20 November 1966 |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/packages/html/movies/bestpictures/music-ar.html |accessdate=17 March 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305090728/http://www.nytimes.com/packages/html/movies/bestpictures/music-ar.html# |archive-date=5 March 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} so rentals of £7–10 million would equate to an exhibition gross of £10–15 million.}} ''Skyfall'', the twenty-third [[James Bond in film|''James Bond'' film]] in the long-running [[Eon Productions#Bond films|Eon series]], became the first film to gross over £100 million in setting a new record at the box-office.{{cite book |title=BFI Statistical Yearbook |year=2013 |edition=2012 |publisher=[[British Film Institute]] |location=London |url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-statistical-yearbook-2013.pdf |pages=[http://www.emagcloud.com/incorporatedesign/BFI_Statisitical_Yearbook_2013_Digital02/pubData/source/BFI%20Statisitical%20Yearbook%202013%20Digital.pdf#page=22 22] & [http://www.emagcloud.com/incorporatedesign/BFI_Statisitical_Yearbook_2013_Digital02/pubData/source/BFI%20Statisitical%20Yearbook%202013%20Digital.pdf#page=32 32] |access-date=8 December 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228060414/http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-statistical-yearbook-2013.pdf# |archive-date=28 December 2013 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} All the record-holders since tracking began have been either partially or fully produced by Americans, although ''The Full Monty'', ''Mamma Mia!'', ''Skyfall'' and ''Star Wars: The Force Awakens'' were UK-US collaborations. Only the grosses that set records are included in the timeline; earnings from subsequent re-releases after the film conceded the record are omitted. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" |+ {{nowrap|Timeline of the highest-grossing film record since 1975}} ! scope="col" | Year of

If the revised estimate is correct and the original gross for ''Titanic'' is not subject to any revision then ''Mamma Mia!'' would not have assumed the record.}} | style="text-align:right;" | 68.6/69.2 |- ! scope="row" | 2010 | ''[[Avatar (2009 film)|Avatar]]'' | style="text-align:right;" | 94.0 |- ! scope="row" | 2012 {{flagicon|GBR}}* | ''[[Skyfall]]'' | style="text-align:right;" | 103.2 |- ! scope="row" | 2016 {{flagicon|GBR}}* | ''[[Star Wars: The Force Awakens]]''{{cite news |first=Ian |last=Sandwell |title='Star Wars: The Force Awakens' retains top spot at UK box office with $8.7m |date=11 January 2016 |work=[[ScreenDaily.com]] |url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/the-force-awakens-retains-uk-lead/5098710.article |accessdate=14 January 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160114082314/http://www.screendaily.com/news/the-force-awakens-retains-uk-lead/5098710.article# |archive-date=14 January 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} | style="text-align:right;" | 123.2 |- class="sortbottom" style="text-align:center; font-size:90%" | colspan="4" | ''Films marked as {{flagicon|GBR}}* are classified as British co-productions by the British Film Institute.

# ''Year of release is used between 1975 and 1990 because it is not known in which year the film set a new record.''}} |} ===British productions=== Since 2007, under English law, films can qualify as British via a cultural test, through an official bilateral co-production agreement or under the European Convention on Cinematographic Co-production. The cultural test utilises a points based system which takes account of cultural content, creative elements and heritage, the nationality of the cast and crew and where the bulk of the production takes place.{{cite web |title=The cultural test for film |publisher=[[British Film Institute]] |url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/supporting-uk-film/british-certification-tax-relief/cultural-test-film#films-certified |accessdate=19 December 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171215234435/http://www.bfi.org.uk/supporting-uk-film/british-certification-tax-relief/cultural-test-film#films-certified#films-certified |archive-date=15 December 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} The application of this process can draw to counter-intuitive conclusions; films not classified as British under this system may have British elements, such as being based on books by British authors and featuring British actors—as was the case with ''[[The Hobbit (film series)|The Hobbit]]'' trilogy—while films that are regarded as quintessentially American—such as ''Star Wars: The Force Awakens'' or ''The Dark Knight''—can result in being classified as British. The most successful British productions in the modern marketplace generally have American investment, with ''The King's Speech'' and ''The Inbetweeners Movie'' the only fully British films to have earned in excess of £40 million. Film series still dominate, accounting for twenty-seven of the top thirty-four films. The remaining films mostly are adaptations of popular novels, stage musicals and television series and biographical films based on historical events. ''The King's Speech'' replaces ''Star Wars: The Force Awakens'' as the most successful British production if the criteria is restricted to solely British-produced films. {{col begin}} {{col 2}} {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |+ British productions with earnings over £40 million since 1989''British productions that have grossed over £40 million'' :*Top films as of 2014: {{cite web |title=Top Films of All Time at the UK Box Office |date=June 2015 |publisher=[[British Film Institute]] |url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-top-films-of-all-time-june-2015.pdf |accessdate=13 August 2015 |page=[http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-top-films-of-all-time-june-2015.pdf#page=7 7] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924012433/http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-top-films-of-all-time-june-2015.pdf# |archive-date=24 September 2015 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} :*{{cite web |title=Top films in 2015 |publisher=British Film Institute |year=2016 |url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-top-films-of-2015.pdf |page=[http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-top-films-of-2015.pdf#page=4 4] |access-date=10 June 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160610191324/http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-top-films-of-2015.pdf# |archive-date=10 June 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} :*{{cite web |title=Top films in 2016 |publisher=British Film Institute |year=2017 |url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-top-films-of-2016-2017-06.pdf |page=[http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-top-films-of-2016-2017-06.pdf#page=5 5] |access-date=23 July 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180306090141/http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-top-films-of-2016-2017-06.pdf# |archive-date=6 March 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} ! {{legend|#b6fcb6|size=100%|text={{†|alt=film currently playing}}|indicates the film's gross has increased since 19 February 2017.}}'' |} {{col end}} ===Non-English language films=== Chinese and Spanish films have achieved the most success at the box-office in the twenty-first century, with three entries apiece among the top ten non-[[English language]] performers. ''The Passion of the Christ'', directed by [[Mel Gibson]], is the top performer and Gibson also has another entry in fourth place with ''Apocalypto''; both films feature [[dead language]]s. Only the top two films were competitive with the top British films. {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |+ Top ten non-English language films of the twenty-first century{{cite book |title=BFI Statistical Yearbook |year=2014 |edition=2013 |publisher=[[British Film Institute]] |location=London |url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/statisticalyearbook2014 |page=[http://www.emagcloud.com/incorporatedesign/BFI_StatisticalYearBook_2014/pubData/source/BFI%20StatisticalYearBook_2014.pdf#page=56 56] |access-date=24 July 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140810175652/http://www.bfi.org.uk/statisticalyearbook2014/# |archive-date=10 August 2014 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |title=Specialised Films |date=November 2015 |publisher=[[British Film Institute]] |url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-films-specialised-films-2015-11-04.pdf |accessdate=10 June 2016 |page=[http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-films-specialised-films-2015-11-04.pdf#page=9 9] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160610211601/http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-films-specialised-films-2015-11-04.pdf# |archive-date=10 June 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} ! scope="col" | Rank ! scope="col" | Title ! scope="col" | Language ! scope="col" | Gross
{{nowrap|{{small|(£ million)}}}} ! scope="col" | Year |- |{{0}}1 ! scope="row" | ''[[The Passion of the Christ]]'' | [[Aramaic]]/[[Latin]]/[[Hebrew]] | align="right" | 11.08 | style="text-align:center;" | 2004 |- |{{0}}2 ! scope="row" | ''[[Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon]]'' | [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]] | align="right" | 9.37 | style="text-align:center;" | 2001 |- |{{0}}3 ! scope="row" | ''[[Amélie]]'' | [[French language|French]]/[[Russian language|Russian]] | align="right" | 5.01 | style="text-align:center;" | 2001 |- |{{0}}4 ! scope="row" | ''[[Apocalypto]]'' | [[Yucatec Maya language|Mayan]] | align="right" | 4.11 | style="text-align:center;" | 2007 |- |{{0}}5 ! scope="row" | ''[[Hero (2002 film)|Hero]]'' | Mandarin | align="right" | 3.82 | style="text-align:center;" | 2004 |- |{{0}}6 ! scope="row" | ''[[House of Flying Daggers]]'' | Mandarin | align="right" | 3.78 | style="text-align:center;" | 2004 |- |{{0}}7 ! scope="row" | ''[[Volver]]'' | [[Spanish language|Spanish]] | align="right" | 2.88 | style="text-align:center;" | 2006 |- |{{0}}8 ! scope="row" | ''[[The Motorcycle Diaries (film)|The Motorcycle Diaries]]'' | Spanish | align="right" | 2.75 | style="text-align:center;" | 2004 |- |{{0}}9 ! scope="row" | ''[[Pan's Labyrinth]]'' | Spanish | align="right" | 2.72 | style="text-align:center;" | 2006 |- |10 ! scope="row" | ''[[Dhoom 3]]'' | [[Hindi]] | align="right" | 2.71 | style="text-align:center;" | 2013 |} ==Highest-grossing films by box-office admissions== Up to and including 2003, the [[British Film Institute]] (BFI) estimate fifty-two sound films have generated over 10 million admissions. The [[European Audiovisual Observatory]] (LUMIERE) have been tracking UK admissions since 1996, and they estimate that twenty-two films have generated over 10 million admissions in that period. Due to conflicting estimates, both sets of figures are presented together here in chronological order. While the two datasets are generally consistent with each other, the estimates from LUMIERE are on average slightly lower than those from the BFI, leading to ''Bridget Jones's Diary'' being included in the BFI dataset but excluded from the LUMIERE one. The largest discrepancy is in the estimates for ''Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone''; there is a difference of 5 million admissions, but LUMIERE do not include any UK data for 2002 while they do for other countries, which may explain the shortfall. Re-releases also exacerbate the differences in some cases: both ''Star Wars Episode I'' and ''Titanic'' were successfully re-released in 2012, and while the LUMIERE dataset includes admissions from the reissues the BFI chart does not. While ''The Lion King'' did not generate 10 million admissions during its original release, it may have accumulated 10 million admissions due to a re-release: according to the BFI it had generated over 8 million admissions during its first run in 1994, and LUMIERE estimate it generated another 2 million with its 2011 reissue. If ''Bridget Jones'' and ''The Lion King'' are included, sixty-five sound films in total have generated over 10 million admissions at UK cinemas. {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |+Sound films with over 10 million admissions ! Since 2007, a legal definition exists for whether a film is British, with ''The Force Awakens'' meeting the criteria and ''Avatar'' not. The Observatory uses its own methodology and reverses this categorization, classifying ''Avatar'' as a British-American co-production and '' The Force Awakens'' as a solo American effort.}} | | align="right" | {{nts|16.51}} | style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web |title=Avatar |work=LUMIERE |publisher=[[European Audiovisual Observatory]] |url=http://lumiere.obs.coe.int/web/film_info/?id=32191 |accessdate=14 November 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180623140847/http://lumiere.obs.coe.int/web/film_info/?id=32191# |archive-date=23 June 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} |- ! Films marked as {{flagicon|GBR}}* are classified as British co-productions.
{{legend|#b6fcb6|size=100%|text={{†|alt=film currently playing}}|indicates the film's gross has increased since 19 February 2017.}}'' |} ==Most popular films== {{Quote box | title=Most successful films |quote = '''Highest-grossing''' * Film – '''''Star Wars: The Force Awakens''''' * British co-production – '''''The Force Awakens''''' * British film – '''''The King's Speech''''' * Non-British – '''''Avatar''''' * Non-English language – '''''The Passion of the Christ''''' * Animated – '''''Toy Story 3''''' '''Admissions''' * Film – '''''Gone with the Wind''''' * British silent film – '''''The Battle of the Somme''''' * British sound film – '''''Spring in Park Lane''''' * Animated – '''''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs''''' | align = right | width = 25em | bgcolor = #F0EAD6}} ===Overview of the twentieth century=== In 2004, the British Film Institute published a list charting [[sound film]]s that generated the most admissions at cinemas in the United Kingdom.{{cite web|title=The Ultimate Film: Researching the Chart|date=November 2004|publisher=[[British Film Institute]]|url=http://old.bfi.org.uk/features/ultimatefilm/methodology.html |accessdate=25 November 2013}} The list is reproduced here ranking the top fifty films released in the UK throughout the [[twentieth century]], defined as covering the period from 1 January 1901 until 31 December 2000. The later films that appear on the BFI list—2001 onwards—are omitted from this chart for the purpose of providing an overview of the century. The second table ranks British sound productions from the twentieth century, five of which are co-productions with other countries. Market conditions, industry practices, demographic and cultural shifts have all impacted on cinema attendance throughout the century. Cinemagoing steadily rose during the 1930s with the arrival of sound and peaked in the 1940s, with 1946 setting a record of over 1,635 million annual admissions; roughly equivalent to thirty visits to the cinema per capita. Attendance dropped off after the [[Second World War]], mainly due to the rising popularity of [[television]]. The decline of the cinema was compounded by the rise of [[home video]] in the 1980s and reached an all-time low of 54 million admissions in 1984.{{cite web|title=The Ultimate Film: Cinemagoing in Britain|date=November 2004|publisher=[[British Film Institute]]|url=http://old.bfi.org.uk/features/ultimatefilm/cinemagoing.html |accessdate=25 November 2013}} With declining attendance came the closure of many cinemas; a trend that was not reversed until the birth of the [[multiplex (movie theater)|multiplex]] in the late 1980s, with annual cinema admissions climbing back up to around 176 million in 2002.{{cite web |last=James |first=Nick |title=Everything you knew about cinema is probably wrong|date=November 2004|publisher=[[British Film Institute]]|url=http://old.bfi.org.uk/features/ultimatefilm/feature.html |accessdate=25 November 2013}} As expected, the 1940s—when cinema attendance was at an all-time high—is the most represented decade on the chart accounting for nearly a third of all entries, while the 1980s—when attendance was at its lowest—is the least represented post-war decade. However, the disparity between the two extremes is not as great as the overall attendance figures suggest due to the fact that vastly more titles were distributed in the 1940s. When comparing the films in the chart, several trends emerge. British films account for half the entries during the 1940s—as opposed to just one entry in the last twenty years of the century—due in part to the [[Cinematograph Films Act 1927|British government imposing quota caps on foreign features]], as well as the inherent difficulties in importing films during the Second World War. With so many men away on [[National service]], films that performed well were also heavily skewed toward female audiences, exemplified by no fewer than four films headlined by [[Anna Neagle]] during this period. Prior to the 1980s when home video became popular, there was also a lot more repeat viewing, with some films during the 1950s and 60s enjoying extended runs—sometimes lasting up to several years—as [[Roadshow theatrical release|roadshows]]. A film's content can also have a prohibitive effect on its success: most films in the chart are either family or children's films, with only two films (''The Godfather'' and ''A Clockwork Orange'') carrying an [[X rating]] or its replacement, the [[18 (British Board of Film Classification)|18 classification]], denying entry to minors.{{cite web|title=The Ultimate Film: Interesting Facts|date=November 2004|publisher=[[British Film Institute]]|url=http://old.bfi.org.uk/features/ultimatefilm/facts.html |accessdate=25 November 2013}} Overall, ''Gone with the Wind'' has generated the most admissions at the UK box office with 35 million and ''Spring in Park Lane'' is the most successful British sound film with 20 million, while 1938's ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs'' is the oldest film in the chart with 28 million admissions. While the chart does not take into account [[silent films]], 1916's ''[[The Battle of the Somme (film)|The Battle of the Somme]]'' is generally regarded to be the most successful film of the silent era, with over 20 million admissions. {{col begin}} {{col 2}} {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |+Top fifty sound films of the twentieth century{{cite web|title=The Ultimate Chart: 1–100|date=28 November 2004|publisher=[[British Film Institute]]|url=http://old.bfi.org.uk/features/ultimatefilm/chart/complete.php|accessdate=14 November 2013}} ! scope="col" | Rank ! scope="col" | Title ! scope="col" | Admissions

All other films are classified as solely British.'' |} {{col end}} ===Overview of the twenty-first century=== Film series and adaptations have been the highest earners in the twenty-first century, with only one film—''Avatar'' in 2009—that is not adapted from a pre-existing property or a sequel emerging as the highest-grossing film of the year. Since the British Film Institute does not regularly track admissions, the only complete metric available for assessing a film's success is the box office revenue, and over a period of time [[inflation]] of the currency becomes a key factor when comparing the relative success of films.{{cite web |title=Top Films of All Time at the UK Box Office |date=June 2017 |publisher=[[British Film Institute]] |url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-top-films-of-all-time-2016-2017-06.pdf |accessdate=23 July 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820175630/http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-top-films-of-all-time-2016-2017-06.pdf# |archive-date=20 August 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} Ticket prices rose rapidly at the beginning of the [[twenty-first century]], with the average cost increasing by over 50 per cent since 2000.{{cite news |title=UK cinema industry economics and turnover: Average ticket price – 2000 onwards |publisher=[[Cinema Exhibitors' Association]] |url=http://www.cinemauk.org.uk/the-industry/facts-and-figures/uk-cinema-industry-economics-and-turnover/average-ticket-price/ |accessdate=29 July 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923203600/http://www.cinemauk.org.uk/the-industry/facts-and-figures/uk-cinema-industry-economics-and-turnover/average-ticket-price/# |archive-date=23 September 2015 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} To this end it is useful to adjust the box office gross for inflation, so a chart ranking films by the [[Real versus nominal value (economics)|real value]] of their earnings is provided alongside a chart of the years' biggest films. After recalculating the grosses using the [[HM Treasury]] UK [[GDP deflator]], ''Star Wars: The Force Awakens'' remains the most successful film of the twenty-first century. The ''Harry Potter'' series is particularly well represented, topping the year on five occasions with two films in the adjusted top ten. The ''James Bond'' films and ''[[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|The Lord of the Rings]]'' trilogy also have a strong presence, with two films apiece among the top ten, adjusted for inflation. The top ten British productions adjusted for inflation are all international co-productions, and—with the exception of ''Mamma Mia''—are all ''Star Wars'', ''James Bond'' and ''Harry Potter'' films. Per the nominal record, ''The King's Speech'' replaces ''Star Wars: The Force Awakens'' as the most successful British production if the criteria is restricted to solely British-produced films. {{col begin}} {{col 2}} {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |+ Top ten films of the twenty-first century adjusted for inflation ! scope="col" | Rank ! scope="col" | Title ! scope="col" | Adjusted

Several unusually large cuckoo clocks have been built and installed in different cities of the world with the aim of attracting visitors, as part of publicity of a [[cuckoo clock]] shop, or to serve as a [[landmark]] for the community and town.
Some have been awarded with the title of "World's Largest Cuckoo Clock" by the ''[[Guinness World Records]]''.
==Argentina== * [[Eduardo Castex]], inaugurated in 1977.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eduardocastex.gob.ar/turismo/monumentos-edificios-historicos/index.html |title=Monumentos y Edificios Históricos |publisher=Municipalidad de Eduardo Castex |language=Spanish |accessdate=January 31, 2013}}</ref> * [[La Cumbrecita]], 2011. * [[La Falda]], 1963.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.argentinaturismo.com.ar/la-falda/cu-cu-de-la-falda.html |title=Cu Cú de La Falda |publisher=Argentina Turismo |language=Spanish |accessdate=January 31, 2013}}</ref> * [[Villa Carlos Paz]], 1958.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.acarlospaz.com/cucu.html |title=Reloj Cu-Cú |publisher=Acarlospaz.com |language=Spanish |accessdate=January 31, 2013}}</ref>
==Brazil== * [[Gramado]]
==Germany== Black Forest * Höllsteig ([[Breitnau]]), 1994. * Niederwasser ([[Hornberg]]), 1995, cuckoo and quail clock.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.house-of-black-forest-clocks.com/attractions.asp?UID=25789745147 |title=Hornberger Uhrenspiele |publisher=House of Black Forest Clocks |accessdate=January 31, 2013}}</ref> * [[Schonach im Schwarzwald|Schonach]], 1981.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dasferienland.de/e/kuckucksuhren.asp |title=Cuckoo clocks |publisher=Das Ferienland |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060301005033/http://www.dasferienland.de/e/kuckucksuhren.asp |archivedate=March 1, 2006}}</ref> * Schonachbach ([[Triberg]]), 1997.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uhren-park.de/shop_content.php?coID=10 |title=World's Biggest Cuckoo Clock |publisher=Uhren-Park |accessdate=January 31, 2013}}</ref> * [[Titisee-Neustadt]]
Other parts of Germany * [[Gernrode]], 1997.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.harzer-uhren.de/riesenkuckucksuhr.html |title=World's largest cuckoo clock outside the Black Forest |publisher=Harzer-uhren |language=German |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090405182352/http://www.harzer-uhren.de/riesenkuckucksuhr.html |archivedate=April 5, 2009 }}</ref> * [[Sankt Goar]], world's largest free-hanging cuckoo clock. * [[Wiesbaden]], 1946.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wiesbaden.de/en/tourism/sightseeing/buildings/Cuckoo_Clock.php?p=3,1,0,9 |title=Cuckoo clock |publisher=Wiesbaden |accessdate=January 31, 2013}}</ref>
==Italy== * [[Canazei]], 2008, with [[carillon]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.girovagandointrentino.it/puntate/2008/inverno_2008_2009/fassa/fassa.htm |title=Val Di Fassa |publisher=Girovagando in Trentino |language=Italian |accessdate=January 31, 2013}}</ref>
==Russia== * [[Penza]], 1974.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://visualrian.ru/images/item/464372 |script-title=ru:Часы с 'кукушкой' |publisher=Visualrian |language=Russian |accessdate=January 31, 2013}}</ref>
==United Kingdom== * Pembridge, Herefordshire (England), 2013.<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22440591 BBC News:Gardener spends over £10,000 to build giant cuckoo clock</ref>
==United States== {{Advert|date=April 2018}} *[[Sugarcreek, Ohio]], 1972. The World's Largest Cuckoo Clock is in downtown Sugarcreek at the intersection of Main and Broadway Street. It has been completely restored and is again fully functional, offering viewers a show every hour and half hour from 9am-9pm except when the outdoor clock is closed in the winter months.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} *[[Douglasville, Georgia]], 1986 (indoor). The world's largest Authentic Cuckoo clock. This clock was commissioned to be built by Jerry Champion, Owner of Champ's Clock Shop in 1986. The manufacturer was Dold Exquisit. They had a retail location in Triberg Germany and the factory was Located at D-7740 Triberg 1 - West Germany Hornberg Strasse 3. Wolfgang Dold was the Seller and his Brother Alfons Dold Carved the clock. An authentic Cuckoo works by Regula was used with special extensions to reach the distance from the works to the Carousel and Bird door. Music box: Reuge 50 note 4 melody. Key factors, Exceeds 13 feet tall (4 Meters), Made in the Black Forest of Germany, Made of Black Forest Trees, Hand Carved, German Cuckoo Works, Can be moved from one wall to another. Not A BUILDING, BILLBOARD, OR PART OF SAME. For Images of the clock visit http://champsclock.com/largestcuckoo.htm
